Poured into an English pint glass, the appearance was a ruddy burnt orange to amber color with a fingers worth of white foamy head that dissipated at a nice pace. Sly sticky lace.
The aroma had some semi-sweet bready to biscuity malts with a mild soapiness. Grassy and earthy hop bitterness. 
The flavor stays true to the aroma, semi-sweet with a subtle bitterness. Mild flowing hops to malts aftertaste with the same sort of finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a good sessionable sort of feel. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt appropriate.
Overall, this was definitely an English pale ale throughout and I could see myself coming back to if I could get it again.

Draft Third of a Pint at GBBF 2010 (Day 3), Earls Court, London Aug 2010 - Golden in colour. Hoppy; resiny and floral hops; good hop bitterness. Malty; grainy malts, caramel. Fruity; grapefruit citrus. Good hop/malt/fruit balance. Easy drinking. (2010-08)

Has a good upfront malt hit, fades pretty quick into a sweetness that is a bit much for me.
Creative brew and I may re-review when I am not blasted.

On tap, on nitro, poured a clear deep golden hue w/ creamy white lasting head. Mild malty aroma. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light to moderate bitter finish. Tastes are ugly fruit, bitter melon, and biscuits. Medium bodied and velvety mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft sample. The beer is a gold color with a white head. Malty dough, nuts, and herbs. Sweet and gets dry in the finish. Medium body and medium carbonation.
Draft - pours yellow white head - nose/taste of coffee, light citrus - medium body
On tap at Fat Heads Pittsburgh. Pours gold with medium frothy white head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is earth and pine. Medium body, juicy hop, grapefruit, light bitterness, good.
Draft - Light fruit and pale malts. Clear gold with a nice white head. Sweet caramel and light hop bitterness.
Pretty decent beer from Boulder. Hoppier than the average English style beer. Has some of the expected mild sweetness and a nice mouthfeel.
Drafy. Hazy deep amber color, medium white head. Aroma of toffee and citrus. Taste is earthy, fruity caramel. OK.
With this kind of hop usage, I dont quite see it as a Brit style. More like kinda, maybe, sorta. Otherwise not bad.
"another pleasant offering from Boulder. nothing that stands out, but a nice sweet/bitter balance, with a very floral nose. fairly basic, but pretty good overall."

Transfer from BA review on 8-10-13-

 Served on tap in an imperial pint glass

 Appearance  The beer is served an orange amber colored brew with tons of tiny carbonation bubbles seen streaming up through the body of the beer. Floating atop the beer was a one finger pure white and foamy head that faded rather fast. Once largely faded, there was a persistent film and a good deal of lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma is sweet of a citrus smell with lots of tangerine and orange and a nice sweet tropical fruit and apricot smell as well. Mixed with these aromas is a little bit of a malty smell as well as some piney and floral aromas.

 Taste  The taste begins with a biscuit and cracker taste mixed with a moderate dose of caramel sweetness. As the taste moves forward the sweeter taste profile changes becoming less caramel like, but more sweet fruit like with flavors of tangerine and pineapple dominating. Mixed with the bready flavors that are initially present is a light citrus hop taste of a grapefruit nature which creates a base for the brew. While the hop is light at first overall, toward the end it gets quite a bit more intense as the grapefruit is joined by other hop flavors of a floral and earthy nature. The transitions of the sweet flavors and the presence of the more potent earthy hop flavor that develops on the tongue at the finish, ends up leaving a moderately earthy bitter and smoother malty flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is average in terms of its thickness and creaminess with a carbonation level that is, as would have been expected from the appearance, composed of tiny carbonation bubbles. Overall the medium bodied nature mixed with the moderate but peppery carbonation were nice for maintaining a more refreshing and easy drinking brew all the while still allowing all the nice hoppy flavors time to be fully appreciated by the tongue. 

 Overall  A rather tasty and smooth tasting brew with a very nice but still quite drinkable level of hop. Overall it is a rather balanced brew and a treat to drink.

Pours an amber light orange color with a floral aroma. Taste is like spring with light malt, and grassy notes. A nature feel in the flavor along with the aftertaste. A slight bitterness that stays on the tongue after the drink. A refreshing beer that was easily drinkable and mildly hoppy.

On tap at Skewed Brewing. Amber orange with a small white head. Malty, fruity aroma. Peaches and pears, maybe. The flavour is interesting. Less sweet than the nose. Booze near the end. Nice bitterness from start to finish.

On tap at Cobblestone Grill. A gorgeous creamy gold pour. Aroma is pretty neutral. Creamy in the mouth with low carbonation. Not very heavy hoppy bite, as it is muted by a light breadiness on the finish. As it warms, it finishes a little more sour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap. Pours orange with white head. Aroma is very cat pee, musty. Taste is a bit astringent, bitter, piney, its okay.

Interestsing ipa. Hoppy and bitter with a strong alcohol finish. Pours light yellow with a cream head. Had at work of beer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught from draught 55. Darkish amber. Not much head. Some malt and toffee and such. OK.
On nitro. Cloudy gold with a large off-white head. Aroma and flavor of bready malt, pale malt, grain, grass, caramel, and toffee. Finish is herbal and grassy.

On tap. Pours copper with white head. Nice lacing. Citrus, earth, melon, white grapes. Moderately bitter and sweet. Mostly smooth body with a little bit of carbonation. Starts out well, but gets a little meh by the time you reach the bottom of the pint glass.
11/19/2011. From bottle. Cloudy orange pour. Light hoppy aromas with malt, caramel and light fruit. Malty flavors with caramel and light hops on the finish.
Big orange pour foamy milkshake head. light hoppy aroma. Hoppy flavor with a strangely sweet finish. Thick start thin finish.

Taster on nitro tap at Black Acre brewpub. Mostly clear, golden orange color. Thin, sort of white head, with good retention. Good, thicker lace. Caramel malt, light metallic. Smooth, creamy, very light carbonation. Lightly sticky finish. Mostly dry. Moderate sweet, lightly zesty. Good rindy citrus notes. Decent English IPA, but not great.

Appearance: Hazy Amber/Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head, Decent Lacing

Aroma: Grainy, Mildly Piney

Taste: Grainy, Mildly Piney, Mildly Floral

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying

Medium amber color with a creamy white head. Aroma is lite but great lite pine and citrus notes. Easy drinker that still has good hop flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had the Nitro. Poured very warm. At sheffields. Cloudy orange with a ton of foamy creamy head. Grain aroma I guess. Bread and Carmel notes. Bitter. Slight hops. Not digging the nitro. Would like to try it w/o

Nitro tap. Creamy plans pillowy tan head. Dark bar so in couldnt make out the hue very well but it looked to be about the color of a Werthers Original. Extremely subtle aroma, can barely describe it in words here. Someone else described the taste perfectly here - it really takes a few seconds for the hops to kick in. Semibitter resin finish, a little less hop punch than I usually enjoy. Solid but not amazing.
Draft at boulder beer taproom DIA. Pours golden with an inch of khaki foam. A little bit of pine on the tongue. Has some really crunchy pine cone flavor on the tongue. Finished a little dry. Solid.

Tap. Wow- this was a pleasant surprise. It was a medium gold color without much head or lacing. It had very nice malt flavors up front and mild carbonation. A touch of hop flavor snuck in as the malt mellowed. Not a whole lot of bitterness and little aftertaste. Nice clean finish. I liked this one a lot.
Slight pine & hops aroma. Not too much to smell. Amber/golden in color with a creamy.off white head. Almost nutty but still hop filled in taste. Pine over rides it all, Tasty.
Tap at Old Chicago. Pour is a hazy orange with thick, lasting white head. Aroma is citrus and floral hops, taste matches the aroma. Really solid.

16oz nitro pour at RFD in DC. Pours a slightly hazy, darker orange with some very cream, lacing white head. I thought the aroma was very nice, clearly a British take on the style, lots of fall fruit, some root veg, standard pine, lemon. some dried leaves. Flavor is malty and sweet, roasted parsnip, pear, lemon, orange, pine. Clean finish. Creamy in the mouth. I thought this was excellent.

I had this from a nitro tap so its changes it. Slightly hazy amber. Hops and fall leaves scent. The beer kind of tastes backwards the malts hit you before the hops. It is a pleasant change that leaves you lightly bitter.

Nitro at craft ale house. Pours hazy light brown or really dark yellow. There is a medium sized off white head, decent lacing. The aroma is a mix of floral notes, citrus, and some toffee and nuttiness. Great mix. The taste is light orange, light bitterness and sweet finish.

From tasting notes.  Bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy dark orange with a small, off-white head.  Aromas of citrus and pine hops, caramel and a touch of tropical fruits.  Nice citrus and pine hop flavor partially balanced with some sweet caramel notes.  More citrus/pine hops and sweet caramel in the finish with some added tropical fruit notes.

Backlog rating, picked this one up in Cleveland several years ago. Hazy deep gold pour with a nicely fluffy, elegant carbonation to it. Soft toffee malts along with Fuggles and shit in the nose. Beefed up, imperial bitter perhaps as a style? Certainly is aggressively hopped, which complements the nice bready malts quite nicely, giving this one a crisp, almost sessionable quality.

Nitro sample pour.  pours a golden/light amber hue with a light fluffed head.  Nose is very light, citrus notes of sweet orange and grapefruit.  Flavor is similar, only much more intense.  Grassy notes all over with orange up front and grapefruit as well.  Quite drinkable.  Nitro provides a different texture, but still smooth.
Nitrous pour. Nice calm pour with a froathy head. Smooth hop flavor and easy on the palate. Nice beer.

Nitro draft at the Khyber Pass. Slightly hazy honey brown amber with a thick tight white head. Strong dry floral notes overtaking a subdued honey sweetness. Dandelion. Lavender. Meyer lemons. Straw. Green bananas. Body is a bit watery. Absence of dark malt flavors makes this an interesting E.S.A..
Sampled at Bearden Beer Market. Hazy golden orange, tight white head. Smells like citrus and rich toffee. Taste is a bit vegetal, with nice woodsy hops and a solid caramel base.
On draft at the brass tap, pours an amber color, aromas of light citrus, and malt.  Flavors are the same, light bitter aftertaste, decent beer, light on the palate.

Draft at Trinity Brass Tap.  Pours a mostly clear copper color with a white head.  Excellent residual lacing along the glass.  Slightly off yet good aroma of hops.  Flavor is very nice.  Good bitterness in the finish.
Bomber. Aroma is very flowery, pineapple, and caramel. Moderately sweet up front, flavors of tropical fruit, caramel, citrusy hops, with a crisp and abrupt finish. Nicely balanced and very drinkable.
Fruity-Tangy Grapefruit and citrus notes followed by a malty and subtle citrus hops flavor.A bit heavy in the body with a slight carbonated kick. Its a simple yet good tasting IPA.

Orange in color with a light white head.  Light palate.  Moderate in both malt and hop characteristics...very middle of the road for me.

On nitro and cask...same are the regular version, but the hop aroma is slightly more pronounced.  In order I prefer, Nitro, then cask, then the regular versions.

Notes: Brewery visit during GABF
Tap: Orange pour with a light head. Earthy, floral, and fruity aroma. Flavor is sweet and mild with grapefruit, clover, and earthy notes.

Originally reviewed: 5/14/09. Pours a cloudy orange/gold with a big white foamy head on top. Retention is a little weak, but the lacing that sticks is all over the place. Smells of malts, breads, and sweet floral hops. 

Light mouth on this one, but oh so creamy. This is a very smooth beer. Big biscuit malty sweetness in this beer. Finishes with just enough of a hop smack on the end, but nothing overpowering or harsh. This is one of the sweeter EIPAs Ive had, but I like it alot. Recommend.

Muddy brown pour. Nose is sweet and well balanced between hops and malt, woody aroma as well. Taste is well balanced as well but no particular palate pleaser dominating. Drinkable and refreshing, finish is dry and short and drinks fast, refreshing. Pair with a piece fruit and cheese. Quaff Score 7 / 10
Pours amber with a white head and aroma of hops and sweet malt. Taste is well balanced, of sweet malt, hops, fruits, and alcohol with a bitter finish. Solid light and drinkable brew.

On tap, pours a cloudy orange color, good thick tannish white lacing, medium to large head that dissapeared. Aromas of tangerine, pine, honey mustard. Taste is honey, pale malt, biscuits, tangerine, and spicy mustard. Finished smooth and refreshing.

18-Mar-12 (22-oz bottle)This is a very tasty, easy to drink beer.  It pours hazy and copper-orange in color with an inch of tightly-knit, off-white head that settles to a thin layer, but holds its creamy presence for the entire session.  The nose is malty, toasty, slightly caramely, and grassy, with toffee, yeasty fruitiness, and a touch of earth.  The malty character is most prominent in the flavor, where its lightly sweet, caramely, and fairly toasty with a modest flavor of toffee.  Gently bitter hops add a flavors of tea, grass, and hay, and its slightly fruity in flavor as well.  Medium in weight and the medium carbonation is very smooth and creamy.  Plenty of ice-crystal lacing adorns the glass.  Overall, this beer is an Americanized version of a British beer.  It is balanced, has no rough edges, and is pretty enjoyable.

12oz bottle poured. hazy copper in color. aroma of flora hops, sweet caramel and bread. taste seemed off, sweet and astringent hops. almost reminded me of an off brand ipa.. this one needs to find its identity. drinkable but not for me.

From the bottle purchased at the Beer Hive in Pittsburgh.  Nothing outstanding or remarkable in this British clone style ale.  Expected more flavor from the imported hops and malts but did not taste anything of distinction.

This beer really riled me up. As a beer itself, I found this to be cloying, even sickly sweet, with a thick body approaching a DIPA that itself could have been pleasing but not given the level of sweetness. The volume of the ingredients (malts and hops) is admirable, and the hops were perfume-like from the moment I popped the top, but it didnt integrate with the malts. And then I read the label, which expands on how this is an English-style beer. Uh-huh. I really dont see it. It hearkens a bit to the golden summer ale, but not to the English strong ales, which usually dont provide the kind of sweetness or bracing hoppiness. It just doesnt work, and it doesnt fit my sense of what this beer should be given that it has this label. So thats a double fault. Bottle.
This beer was very good, nice and hoppy with a decent malt character and a subtle sweetness.

Pours a cloudy gold with an off white head. Nose and taste is of floral hops, grain, hay, and a touch of fruity sweetness. A very solid brew, not a style I seek out often, but a nice change up from time to time.

This beer has moved to my top five for (gotta have it in my fridge at all times category).  Very sweet and  a great citrus taste.  I think this is very similar to Bells Two Hearted, but the aroma isnt there.  If you are a fan of Bells Two Hearted do yourself a favor and give this one a go!

6.3% on tap at DIA. Pours with a very lively carbonated (from tap with an overflowing head). Massive billowy off-white head. Hazy golden-orange hued body. Aromas are bready, grainy, grassy malty, caramel with light esters. Flavors are floral and nicely bready with some light british esters. There was also a strong metallic note sadly. Lively bubbles.

A: The pour is clear golden-amber color with a white head.  

S: Smells quite buttery with lots of grassy and herbal hops.  Sweet popcorn and bready malts.  A bit of pine and citrus peel, too.  Not a very pleasant aroma.

T: Sweet bread, toffee, and caramel with quite a lot of butter.  Herbal and grassy hops and a weird, but very strong, perfume note.

M: Medium bodied with medium carbonation.  

O: This beer was just dreadful.  Far too much butter.
Poured a hazy reddish gold.  Very hoppy aroma with pine and resin.  Taste of vegetables and herbs.  Lots of hops, but not too bitter.  Creamy and smooth.  Overall very nice.

On tap at Burgatory. Terrific nose. Fresh hops, piney and resinous. Very aromatic. Light sweet malt, ozone, rubber, patchouli. Medium golden amber with light haze, topped with thin lacing white head. Medium heavy body with medium carbonation. Starts hoppy with tons of flavor, mild sweet malt and bit bitter hops, not harsh. Fairly mild finish and after considering the nose and taste.

On tap Patricks Pub in Crescent PA.  A decent hoppy aroma, orange pour,well balanced hoppy, hints of grapfruit taste with malt.  I liked this style and this beer.  A brew that even Ginny tasted and enjoyed.  Good dry finish, medium body.
Floral and citrus hops with light biscuit and toasted malts in the aroma.  Very fresh tasting hops and light malty backbone.  Medium bodied with decent carbonation that cut it down a bit.  Impressed.
Pours golden orange with a white head.  Aroma is pine, hops and caramel.  Taste is tart and sweet.  Medium mouthfeel and smooth drinking.

A barely hazy reddish beer with a medium beige head that leaves decent lacing.  The aroma is floral and grapefruit, very nice though a bit faint.  The flavor is fairly balanced, with a bit of bitterness and malt sweetness, but highly drinkable.  A very good beer.
Hazy golden with a creamy white head.  Floral sweet caramel malt aroma.  Very earthy hops up front followed by musty molasses flavors.

(thanks J.S.). Amber colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is dfloral and fruity hops with some grassy and malty notes. Flaviour is crisp malts along with fruity and floral hops. A rather pleasantly balanced brew.

Good, good bottle.  Huge hop aroma, with some grain mixed in.  Tastes grainy, mildly sweet, with a cool citrus fade that peters out a little too soon, but not enough to put you off this tasty beer.  (10/08)

Pours a dark golden color that borders on amber with a huge fluffy whit head that sticks around for a while. Wow what a nice nose. Spicy floral and resinous hops with hints of toffee and maybe some butter. Gives off and almost herbal aroma at times. Flavor follows the aroma quite well. Starts with a fruity floral and resinous hop that melds into a bit of an herbal note. The some malts come forward to reveal some toffee and a hint of butter. Finishes with a lingering spicy herbal note. Creamy resinous mouthfeel, rather full body, ample carbonation. Wow I enjoyed that one although it is not what I expected while opening the bottle. Well done Boulder, and welcome to NH.

Slightly hazy copper with a soapy beige head with slight lacing. Aroma of bread, caramel, citrus, and sugar. The taste was really sweet fruit and malt with a mild bitterness. Medium bodied. Not something Id buy again.

12 fl oz bottle from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Clear amber with a nice tan foam.
  
Aroma:  Strong pine hops with some dusty notes, earthy, nutty British-style malts with hints of caramel and toffee, a bit of marmalade and rye bread crust, some berries, a little peach/apricot, citrus, nice.
  
Palate:  Medium body with very restrained effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Like an American IPA with plenty of mice jammy marmalade, oranges, a little pine, crunchy caramel malt, some brown sugar a peppery note, fruity, sweet, nice; lightly sweet with decent bitterness and a fruity, malty finish.

British-American-style ale.  Enjoyable.
Brown with white head. Aroma is caramel, hops, malt, earthy. Taste is fairly light with a faint bitterness, kind of like an ESB. A bit grainy, not too bad.

On tap at Bodega, a servers suggestion to start the night, not a great one...A dark but clearish gold, orange highlights, light head, not much retention or lacing...Aroma is sweet caramel to start, light citrus and some hops but not much...The taste is malty to start then a lot of bad hops, harsh, metallic, boring. nothing special.

(Draught) gold amber color with a film of white bubbles. Nose has that west coast hop profile, citrus, orange, light aroma and cane sugar. Taste is mildly bitter, biscuity and yeasty, cracker, unsweet tangerine. Velvety carbonation, melon and earthy linger.

Bottle on 12/11/2010 from the World Beer Festival - Richmond. Slightly hazy golden amber body with a large rocky off-white head. Sweet floral and citrus hop aroma. Sweet floral and dry malt flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

(Sample Date: 12/11/2010   Source:Other)   Spicy resiny hop aroma with sugary caramel notes. Cloudy orange golden with small white head. Flavor is similar to aroma. Medium body and mouth. Finish is medium to sweet with moderate residual bitterness.

Cask gravity @ G´BBF 2010. Pours a golden color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity hoppy citrus aroma. Fruity malty weak hoppy flavor with some hints of citrus. Has a fruity malty finish with hints of hops in the aftertaste.

grapefruity and pine apply aroma with sweet malts in the background quite nice..high marks for appearance as well..cloudy amber deep orange color pure white foamy head plenty of lacing..tastes of citrus pine and perhaps floral hoppiness and a fruity maltiness which is unusual in a nice way..easy to drink,medium bodied with a sweet aftertaste bitter on the tongue..overall cant find a whole lot to complain about very pleasantly surprised and inexpensive too

12 oz. bottle. Pours a medium white head, over a clear amber (SRM 7) body....nose is floral with resin, pine....taste is sweet malts to start, then melon like fruit flavors with pineapple and finishing with light hop bitter \....mouth feel is medium, carbonation also. This is unbalanced. The malts are very sweet and fruity and dominate the hops over much. It needs more bitterness to be balanced. BJCP 6/3/10/4/6

Nice aroma with a strong spruce smell with a hint of citrus, follow with a light caramel finish. Lightly bitter with an easy sweet ending. Has a nice bitter finish that ends with a long, light body. Overall, a very nice beer. Just enough hops to live up to the name, but ends with an excellent smooth malty finish.

Copper orange with a fluffy head of pith, lace sticks to the sides of my glass before receding into a thick blanket of bubbly foam. Betcha didnt think Id get that all in one sentence, huh? Hah! Now, back to the beer. Her nose is right out of the forests of Boulder if I do say so myself. Pine needles and air heavy with wet pine and forestry esters meet and greet with generous aplomb. Underneath is the dry woodiness of bark followed by the sticky sappy bounty found within. Orange and mango skin provides some nice tropical bitterness to remind us that hops arent all about the evergreen, nosiree. Make no doubt though; pine is still the main star of my snuffing and now quaffing show. Crisp with a touch of orange sweetness which greets first and then steps aside for pine, fir, and trees ohmy. Pine bark mingles with the orange skin while sticky sap and piney resins gleefully coat my lips and gently braise the top of my tongue while orange and mango is a gentle river of sweetness underneath. Quaff and repeat, and I dont mind if I do.


Boulder may have skiing going for it, but personally, Id be going for the beer. Sure, you might find me playing out in the snow, brew in hand, but dont expect these feet to ever see any kind of skis, boards, or whatnot. Im a professional lounger and Id be more than happy to lounge the afternoon away with some Cold Hop to keep me company.

Beer poors light copper and clear with a thin white head that stays in a ring around the glass.  Aroma is huge grapefruit and somewhat distracting.  Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter, but huge hop flavor, again grapefruit.  Palate is nice and inviting leaving me craving more.  Overall the beer is intersting, I like the big hop flavor, but Im not as big of a fan of the hop choice.  Grapefruit seems too distracting.
The brewery is one of the coolest we have ever been to.  The tap is covered in ice and the beer that comes out of it is REALLY good!  Drink it cold and enjoy
Cask gravity at GBBF 2010.  Hazy gold, just the hops, just died, some toffee.  But hops just killed by the journey.  It could be good, but it isnt

Pours a clear dark golden color.  Aroma of grapefruit, pine, lavender and brown sugar.  Flavor is grapefruit and floral with a subtle roasted grain and pine.  A touch of sweetness balances this beer incredibly well.  More floral an fruity than most English Strong Ales, but much appreciated!
Tap. Semi-hazy orange pour with a thin white head. Big grapefruit hop aroma. Taste is earthy, fresh hop, light citrus. Yummy.

12 oz. bottle, dated 09/01/2010 and consumed a month later on 10/05/2010.  Pouring a very slightly hazy, dusky, rust-orange amber color, the body supports a small, frothy, cream tinted head.  Settling to a patchy film, the crown leaves dense, tattered bands of hard lacing all around the glass.  The nose is hopped at American IPA levels, sporting juicy grapefruit peel, orange pith, and lemon zest, along with some dank grass and some very earthy, dusty floral notes.  Underlying malts are biscuit driven in the English pale style, also suggesting day old bread.  The more it warms, the more dry, dank, and grassy it gets, even showing some cannabis notes.  Flavors are similar, showing some sweet caramel and biscuit up front, but quickly turning aggressively bitter, biting with very peppery, earthy flower and grass notes, with lemon peel coming through to a lesser extent.  Dank hops linger for a long while after the finish.  The palate is substantial in body, sticky with malty sugars and under carbinated, drinking kind of heavy for what it is. Alcohol is too prominent.  I like alot of what this beer has to offer, but it has its fair share of flaws as well.

Bottle 355ml 
Aroma :  mature nose. Solid malt backing with proper decisive hop profile. Citrus yet with enough British feel wrapped in heavy malts.8+ 
Appearance: good clear amber shade. Large fine creamy head with some lace on walls.
Flavor and Palate: medium plus bodied. Frontal bitterness is quiet empowered, slight nuttiness followed with oily heavy malts. Secondary showed more of that British nutty woody hop. Alcohol is present yet very smooth. Dangerously drinkable ale.

9/12/10.  12oz bottle.  Clear amber pour that leans toward orange when held to the light, under a fluffy off-white head that lasts pretty well.  Rich English aroma with caramel, malt, and black tea, with a hint of citrusy hops.  The flavor is sweet and caramelly with black tea as well, but with floral hops that linger in the back of the throat.  Not bad.
Sampled at Great Lakes Brew Fest in Racine, WI.  Hoppy esb not much aroma, decent.  Hops definitely present in both aroma and flavor.

Sample at Buckeye Beer Engine. Hazy orange pour with a medium white head. Nice hop nose consisting of citrus, grass and pine and only a little bit of that potato character that I find to be so prevalent in Mojo and Mojo Risin. Malty flavor up front quickly turning to spicy hops and a lasting earthy finish.

Bottled.  Pours a rich golden color with a fair head.  Floral and citrus aromas abound and upon taking a draw, I discovered one of the most well-balanced Ales Ive had in a while.  A good amount of hops makes it peppy, and mixed with the lacy smoothness of an ale gives a unique combination.  A must try.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear, deeper golden colored body with a finger-width, frothy, off-white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is a moderate amount of somewhat rough, earthy citrus hops. Some crisp pines and sweet florals too with a light malt backing consisting of grain and a hint of caramel. Flavor is similar. Somewhat sweet graininess up front with a bit of a watery caramel. Hops quickly come in and grow towards the finish. More earthy citrus and crisp grass with some semi-sweet florals and pines. Finishes with an increased grapefruit grass and a higher bitterness. Lots of hops in a lengthy aftertaste with a bit of a toasty bread creeping in. Light-medium, very crisp body with a soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty nice beer. Lots of fresh, crisp hop flavor with an easy drinking, refreshing balance. Solid.
Pine & Grapefruit hop aroma, golden medium bodied ale.  I dont think Ive had an English Strong Ale quite like this.   I couldnt pin the style down when sampling it.  My best guess it was a 2XIPA.
4th August 2010. GBBF. Hazy gold beer with a suddy white head. Sweetish hops - a little orange and pineapple. Finishes floral and dry.
Draft at brewpub.  Pours a clear amber with a thin tan head.  Herbal hop aroma with lots of pine.  Balanced malt and hop flavor.  Very bitter with lots of pine.  Basil note

poured out of the bottle a medium gold with a nice off-white head.  Good retention and fairly clear.  The aroma surprised me.  Based on the look of the bottle, I did not expect all that much, however it had a nice citrusy, floral, and earthy nose.  The body was medium and the taste is pretty good. Earthy, citrusy hop flavors almost balanced with a sweet malty backbone, accompanied by a lasting nice bitter aftertaste.  Ill be getting this one again, strange looking bottle and all.
bottle.  Malty smell of fresh cake, light hops, cherry, buttered biscuit, hay, caramel.  Medium bodied, smooth, creamy.  A lasting bitterness on the finish.  This is excellent.
Floral bouquet, citrus and pine aroma. Citrus fruits, caramel and toffee flavors. Malted backbone with a nice flavorful lingering bitter finish. Full and hearty mouthfeel. A very enjoyable strong.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle dated Oct. 4, 2010. It pours a slightly cloudy amber-golden tone with a quarter inch of off-white foamy head and busy carbonation.  The aroma is a muted floral hoppiness with a vaguely sweet maltiness trying to insert itself into the tasting. The taste is full of New Zealand hops but there is also a kind of sharp graininess trying to intoduce itself to the drinker (me). A flowery aftertaste.  Different but most definitely an IPA.
(Cask GBBF) a bit subdued ...not that floral or aromatic ...not really or that "British" IMO .   Some husky grains ..caramel ...
Cask at GBBF 2010. An amber coloured pour with a smallish head. Fruity, hoppy aroma. Tastes fruity, hoppy, grassy.
12 oz bottle. Aroma is slightly piney and floral. Light  for the ABV, with light bitterness on the back of a sweet fruit and flower note.
Floral hop aroma.  Clear, golden, thin white head.  Very refreshing, hoppy beer... key difference to many IPAs.  Mild carbonation, light / medium body.  Good all around beer.

Cask at Blind Tiger, New York, NY.  Served luke warm with clear bronze colour. Grapefruity nose. Sweet with clean, rounded mouthfeel and medium body. Vodka and tequila is astonishingly present. Fruity and  rough with a bit of resin. At 20-25C its not exactly cellar cool, perhaps thats why it feels so fiercely peppery alcoholic and overall extremely harsh.

Light bodied beer.  Had at Capital Ale House 7/24/10.  A bit of hops on the nose, malts, slight wheat smell.  I taste hops, slight bread oatmeal.  Not much going on okay beer.  Just not impressed for the most part.

On tap @ brewery.  An excellent example of an English Ale.  Tart with a bit of sweetness, but lots and lots of Hops.  Aroma reminded me of herbs and bread.  Minimal white head lingered above a perfect clear amber ale.  Full body with just the right carbonation and long finish.  Great beer!

bottle-bright hazy orange with a small soapy white head.  fruity, earthy hop nose very clean for the style and for being English.  Sweet malt, earthy hop flavors-very pleasand and no sign of nasty english yeast.  Probably used an american variety.  palate is fantastic-crisp and clean like i said for this style.  One of the better beers from this brewery.  I would have this again and thats saying alot from this style and brewery!

Bottle.  Pours clear orange with a fluffy beige head that leaves pretty nice lacing.  Spicy citrus and pine on the nose, along with funky overripe papaya, pepper, orange, and caramel.  Sweet caramel malt and rich English malt dominate the flavor, with slightly bitter citrus rind in the finish.  Full-bodied.  Nice beer.

This beer is a clear iced tea color with a medium rocky off-white head that dissipates steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Floral hops and fruit in the nose. Medium body with an earthy malt character and flavors of fruit and more floral hops. The finish is malty and earthy with a light hops aftertaste. Decent brew overall.

I really like this one. Hazy golden color accompanied by a slim white head. Aromas of pine, spruce, and floral hops. The taste follows the nose, tastes of the woodland, but there is something else here that makes it stand out among other ipas: this beer tastes of sweet fruits as well, some type of citrus. It was a nice touch and noticeable on the aftertaste. Would order again. Correction: this is not an ipa, but it really seems to fit the bill.

On tap at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. and served to a shaker with a clear, orange/amber hue, modest, white head foam that diminished to a ring and film, and left some draping patches of lacing. The nose was perfumey mid-fruit, orange, light tartness, and a hint of yeast. The flavor was similar with a nice balance of just medium hop and malt content, with the hop showing a nice, "back of the tongue" bitterness. The body was medium to light, and enjoyably drinkable.

Draught. Clear orange with small white head. Big earthy citrus hops, typical Boulder Beer hop profile, also honey and caramel. Taste is similar, lots of earthy notes, some citrus. Gets worse and beer warms, not the best sign. Big bitter finish. Crisp and refreshing until it gets warm. Like the name says, it should be cold.
Druaght.  Poured a dark copper color.  Aroma big floral hops.  Taste: big bite of bitterness at the beginning. makes u smack your lips.  nice crisp, dry finish.
Well done.  This has a nice citrusy, floral hop flavor with a touch of sweetness that really complements the bitterness.  On draft.

Pours orange with a decent  white head and plenty of lacing. Aroma is piney and very malty / earthy. Taste of pine, malt, earthiness, and grass. This is a farily dry ale, typical of the style, but with a very solid bitter hop flavor in the end which I really enjoyed.

draft.  Clear golden ale w/ an odd grape-muscadine nose, wft.  This is present in the taste too, again wft, but there is an enjoyable hop bitterness.  Drinkable & tasty, just confusing to me.  More alcohol than I expected but too little to be an "English strong".  Basically too much WTF for me.
A clear gold pour, almost no head.Scent is hops and some fruit and grass. Taste is really good, oh its subdued hops. Enjoy!

Bottle.  Best by (I think):  08/04/10.  A clear copper pour with a smallish light-tan head.  Sweet cereal grains, light breadiness, a hint of caramel, and some citrus fruits make up the aroma.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied.  The taste is sweet upfront with some cereal grains and a bit of caramel.  Biscuity in the middle.  A tangy finish with some lemon and lightly drying grapefruitiness.  More resiny and bitter at the end than I had expected.  Still, refreshingly poundable.

Bottle poured a very warm orange color with a yellowish head that was pretty thick. Smelled spicy and bitter, tasted very smooth and delightful with a heavy mouthfeel. A really nice finish that wasnt too bitter, but didnt let you forget that it was a hoppy brew. Nice beer.

Clear orange pour with a light offwhite head.  Aroma is floral, a bit resinous hops with some earthy spiciness and some toasty, earthy English malt character.  Flavor is malty, sweet toffee and caramel.  Much hoppier than most of my previous experience with this style. A pleasant surprise, yum

Clear yellow pour with medium carbonation and a large pillowy off white head. The aroma holds a soft caramel-toffee english style malt character with very sprucy-pine and floral hop notes. Quite the hop character for the style. The flavor is also quite how forward- lots of earthy resinous evergreen with juicy-fruit floral notes and a backbone of caramel toffee malt. Very impressed by the hop profile on this one- very atypical for the style, but throughly enjoyable. The mouthfeel is soft and supple with medium effervescence and a clean, ever so resinous finish.

Bottle purchased at Buyrite Liquors in South Plainfield NJ.

Appearance: Pretty clear orange body with a generous off white head. Loads retention and lacing on this one.

Smell: Slight touch of alcohol, sweet honey malt, some floral hops, strong British charecter, a bit earthy.

Taste: Like a British IPA but with a larger dash of hops. Buttery but hoppy too. Grapefruitish but Fuggle like at the same time. Interesting.

Mouthfeel: Lots of carbonation help with this slightly thick medium bodied brew.

Drinkability: Not my session beer of choice but I could see making an decent evening out of this one if I had to.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-16-2008

hazy gold, creamy beige head, highly effervescent, soft medium body, crisp medium co2.

aroma: minerality, piney floral hops, fresh bread.

T1= sweet bready malt, leafy hops, fruity grain.
T2= grassy hops, pretzel skin, astringent, toasted grain.
T3= slight toffee malt, piney hop bitterness.

niether the malt nor the hops seem fresh and full, but its creamy and balanced. would be better with some pub grub.

12 Oz.  Pours a light clear gold with two finger size head that hols its retention.  Aroma is a balance of hops and barley with notes of grain, citrus, grass, and cereal.   Taste comes on with a very nice medium strong bitterness quickly balanced by its light barley and malt tones.  Beer is medium to light bodied with a smooth easy drinking palate that finishes with almost sticky bitter bite.  Overall a very nice English style ale with a little more hops than most.
Pours copper with an off white head.  Smells of wildflowers, grassy, some fruity hints.  Tastes of caramel, some fruity elements and a sweet citrussy finish.

12 oz bottle. Dark amber, slightly cloudy with a solid head that holds a light foam to the end. Floral and citrus in the hops, good balance with caramel malt. Maintains some light sweetness with hoppy bitterness at the finish. Overall very good, but not a typical british ale.

Pours a murky, pale iced tea color with a small off-white head that leaves patchy lace upon the glass. The nose is a pleasant, subdued blend of mildly fruity, floral and pale malt notes. On the light side of medium-bodied with solid carbonation and a nice, soft mineral finish that transitions to an equally soft bitterness that comes forward after the swallow. An exercise in flavorful subtlety, this is a beer that really grew on me the deeper I got into the glass: a round pale malt backbone with a well integrated blend of floral and fruity hop notes alongside a mild mineral water quality. This is a really nice beer; a pleasant surprise and definitely a favorite from this brewer.

Rockies Brewing Company--Boulder Beer Company--cold hop british-style ale--Looking Glass Series 7th Release--2009 12 oz. Bottle.  6.80% ABV--46 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  IPA--British--Light sediment.  Off white rocky lacy medium head.  Cloudy dark amber orange color.  Floral English hop ester front.  Doughy creamy mild cloying sweet malty caramel fruit ester body.  Refreshing mellow hop spice mild citrus lingering fruit end.  British BC IPA.  Yeasty.  Sampled 6/9/2009.  6-Pack $9.00.

Pours amber gold with a light quickly dissipating head. Smells of light gentle hops, cold fruit salad, malt. Hops taste a bit old and faded but not by much. Pleasantly light and bitter at first. Tastes of grain maybe barley. Mildly sweet. Good balance, good beer.

Bottle shared by Eyedrinkale: Hazy/milky pour with a wispy white head. Nutty aroma with some soft citruses. Feels quite British. The body is silky and light. The flavor is quite nutty as well. Mild husk notes with a soft citric/herbal hop presence dries it out nicely. Feels British. Has a soft citrusy hop back. A nice session.

bottle best by nov12/2009 consumed on 10/14/2009.

pale coppery amber colored pour with a soft whitish head and random spots of foam. 

it smells an awful lot like sundance... take out the sweet malt, add in some pine and orange pith... voila.

the flavor is the same as the aroma... not as sweet though it is full of pale maltiness. it is more leafy than dirty... orange pith, orange meat and a piney spicy finish. the hoppiness actually numbs the tongue a bit.

it is medium bodied... maybe a little thin... but mixed with prickly carbonation and i could drink a lot of it. 6/3/7/4/14/3.3

Pours a hazy apricot with a frothy head that dissipates rather quickly. Mostly floral hops in the aroma, with a healthy dose of English caramel malts. The flavor is a lot louder than the aroma. Lots of citrus and herbal hop flavors blend well with the English malts. Slightly bitter hops on the finish, but mostly on the sweet side. Very ipa esque, with a nice mix of flavors.

Pours mostly clear orange with a foamy white head. Aroma is floral hops, toffee, caramel, and orange. Taste is rich roast malt with a heavy dose of hops. Slightly resinous finish. I think this beer is a great balance of bitter and sweet, definitely English influenced but with an American hop twist.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James. Pours golden-orange with a lovely white, pillowy head. Aroma of lavender, pine, hops, some malt accents, and hints of tart fruit. Mild mouthfeel and body. Very smooth and easy-going brew. Good balance of alcohol and flavor. Decent English strong.

Pours cloudy yellow orange hue with thin white lace.

Nose is somewhat tame for an IPA, with a distinct orange citrus aroma.

Palate is very fruit-juicy oriented with some pleasant malt in the backdrop. Finish is medium length and nothing terribly special, but nothing bad either.

Overall a nice ale, good, but not great by any means.

Tap at the Denver Airport taphouse.  Orange hued golden color.  Very pretty.  Thin white head.  Fresh hop aroma with a hint of vanilla bean.  Taste is full of fresh hop cones, earthy and grassy.  Tastes like wet hay.  Malt is decent but unnoticeable until you give it some thought.
12 oz bottle split with Pat.  Pours an orange hazy body with lots of chunky sediment. Aroma is grassy, pine hops. Taste is smooth, pine hops.

nice hoppy nose, then suprisingly flat flavor with hop finish.  Sounds like a criticism, but I really liked it.  Also, quote notable was that there was tons of yeast floating around in it, which looked cool.

Pours a light orange with a moderate white head and lots of effervescence. It has an aroma of bitter grapefruit, regular hops and a hint of sweetness from the malt. The taste, likewise, is a combination of bitter grapefruit, hops and just a small hint of the malt. Its rather full-bodied and overall an excellent beer.
Pours a lasting ring of white head with a golden-amber body.  Floral and pine aromas.  Flavors of bubblegum, pine, catpee, and floral.  Finish is dry and bitter.

Good beer, defintely a little different. T leafy is a good  word, read earthy as well. Not skunky not metallic but some notes of those w/o them being the right words to use.
A good beer Id drink this.

Poured hazy orange with white head, smelled of grassy hops with a slight bready note.  Taste of fresh grassy hops with a yeasty malt with a disappointing lack of a real bitter finish.  Also left a strange taste in the mouth, but a decent english style ale.

A: Pours a nice golden color with a puffy head. The head dies down to a half finger and leaves behind some beautiful lacing.

S: Nice floral aroma. Pine and fresh cut grass. There is a touch of an acidic citrus aroma lingering in the background.

T: Nice brew. Starts of with a nice pine hop bite. A bready maltyness then overtakes you and finishes with a nice bitter sweetness. Well balanced beer.

M: Medium bodied and dry in the finish.

Pretty nondescript and rather bleh.  Not a bad beer mind you, but nothing to make it stand out.  British hops, some caramel malts...in muted terms for both.  Some Brit out there might say thats how beer is supposed to be, but I need a bit of something to jar me out of my complacency.
Now this has a hoppy aroma, but especially bittering hops. The head doesnt last long and the flavor is actually a bit flat. Some hops though an easy finish. Definitely english-style.

Bottle at The Brickskeller, Washington DCHazy deep blond color. Pungent passion fruit aroma. Medium body, with a good toffee flavor, no sweetness, but quite good resiny and fruity hop. Bitter final, but with less emotions. Less interesting than all the European beers with Nelson Sauvin, but still peasant.
Bottle, $1.85 at Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville. Pours golden with a small head. Smells of citrus hops, pepper, and clover. Orange peel and clover in the mouth.
A strong hop taste to this one, which might not be cool if you arent in the mood for strong tasting beer.

Dark gold color, nearly clear. Explosive (and eventually rocky) head that leaves thick lace on the glass side.

Pleanty of hop nose; attractive and inviting, if you like hops.

Good malt start, but the hop is the star. Lots of spicy pine in the aftertaste. Quite dry. Moderate body with low carbonation.

This is a tasty beer but is the run-of-the-mill hoppy near IPA.
Nice pour. Dark gold color with no foam. Aroma has hops, dried fruits, and pine. Earthy taste, but not too dry. Pretty good IPA taste. Refreshing.

Pours a hazy gold/orange color with a thin white head. Aroma is grass, some lager notes a small citrus hop nose. Flavor is similar. Clean with a little bit of malt sweetness. Kind of funky but not bad.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a light amber color, the classic hue of an English pale ale.  The nose brings a refreshing character of west coast citrusy hops, with an especially prevalent note of Casecade.  The palate starts bitter up front, lending a note of grapefruit and a slight touch of resin.  However, the beer appears to have been left to dry hop for too long, as there is a grassy character that begins near the mid-palate, and that detracts considerably from the rest of the flavors that are otherwise quite good.  Notes of crystal malt come through subtley in the mid-palate to finish, as does an earthy set of esters from the English yeast strain.  Overall, nicely subtle and promising, both in terms of its English and American characteristics, however, in need of some refinement.

Had this on nitro and it was very weak, but thats the nitro for you. Nice hop profile of pine, grass and citrus. Could tell that it was a british style pale although it being on nitro was harder to. Decent ale, Ill have to try it in bottle.

Had on tap at BeerRun in Charlottesville, VA.  Aroma is of floral hops.  Taste is balanced with a medium body, flowery hops and grass.  Finish is nice and balanced too.  Overall, a good, well put together beer.

Bottle.  Quite the explosive pour -- with a hazy, orange-yellow final product.  Sweet citric aroma, followed with a nicely put-together beer of light grapefruit, pine and floral sweetness.  Excellent.  (#3725, 10/31/2009)

Amber pour with an off white head. Aroma of caramel and hops. Flavor was stronger than I expected with a lot of hops coming through. Slight bitterness at the finish but well balanced with the caramel malts.

Barley and wheat bread nose. Clear amber, headless. Burst of grapefruit flavor with a touch of lime. Some orange peel finish too. Rather like Mountain Dew beer, if that makes sense, just malty and more bitter. The hops are there and in full effect.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2010 Hazy golden pour with creamy white head ... very creamy citrusy floral hop aroma sweet malty earthy taste and a citrusy hop finish a good balanced brew and drinkable but nothing special .... on nitro pour sweet malty aroma and a very sweet citrusy hop and caramel malf flavor lots of lacing and too sweet not a fan of this on nitro at all

Got it in a winter seasonal section, but it certainly wasnt that. Billed as a strong ale, but feels more like a traditional IPA. Referred to as "british style", but aside from its bitter finish I dont get it. Not as malty as Boulders beers usually are, and probably my least favorite of their beers.

Appearance: Slightly hazy orange color with a foamy, off-white head.
Aroma: Pine hops, some biscuit and dough notes on the malt side.
Flavor:Earthy, pine hops with a good malt backbone.  Some toast and biscuit notes.
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and a medium-long, bitter finish.
Overall: I was surprised to see this classified as an English Strong Ale as I was certain it would be an IPA.  I couldnt tell it had 6.5% alcohol either.  Shows what I know.

tap at beer engine.  pours a clear dark golden with an offwhite head.  nice lace.  notes of doughy malts, caramel, bread, citrusy hops.  too doughy and bready.  underwealmed.  hops are masked by this crap.  some citrusy hops shine through, grapefruit orangepeel shine through on the nose.

Tap at Bukowskis Tavern, Boston, September 2009. Amber colour. Slight haze. Good solid leafy hop character throughout. Quite estery fruit. Grapefruit comes through strongly at the finish. Nice firm mouthfeel. A good, tasty beer. Cant say it seemed to me very British in style though.

12oz bottle.  Orange-tan with a slight haze.  Minimal thin head.  Very nice hoppy aroma, lots of citrus and pine.  Solid bitterness on top of a respectable toasty malt backbone.  The hops almost have a cooling effect, very refreshing.  Sort of a hybrid of a West Coast IPA and an English Bitter.  I have to agree with Lubiere below me, there is a slight green pepper taste as well, of course steeped in hoppy goodness.  A good beer, well worth a try.

This beer was a transparent amber in color with a short tan head. The smell is hoppy and sweet. It has a really nice aroma. The taste is malty and hoppy at the same time, very nice balance. The hop flavor is slightly bitter and grassy. This is a pretty good beer! This is now my favorite Boulder Beer brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-29-2007 15:35:26

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2009 Pours a hazy copper color with some white head.  Hops are very apperent in the aroma, along with citrus.  Tastes more like an IPA than an English Strong Ale.  Hops are the main flavor with a hint of caramel. Medium bodied. This is a pretty good and very unique English Strong Ale.

A orange amber ale with a thin creamy off white head. A nice malt with fragrant British hops, peppery , strange meaty notes. In mouthm a rather bizarre IPA, with biscuitty malts, floral hops, green pepper, meaty notes. Medium bodied. On tap at Boulder Brewing Taphouse, DEN, August 28, 2009.

very smooth, clean crisp IPA tasting beer. Very agreeable with my upset belly. sweet and bitter, floral .Like the Sierra Nevada Harvest Ale. Bottle at 2nd Annual Treasure Coast Beerfest in Ft. Pierce, Fla.
Hazy orange with a medium white head.  Fruity and hoppy aroma matches the taste.  Watery texture finishes smooth and mildly sweet.

Pours a crystal clear amber into the glass, with an offwhite sudsy head that leaves soapy lace.  The nose is of big, grassy hops and some sourgrains.  Flavors of caramel, lemongrass, grassy hops and some silage grains.  The finish closes on a grassy, earthen hop note.  The mouthfeel is easily smooth, with a sharp, biting texture.  I can feel the British invasion, but definitely the bold American take on the style.  Interesting offering, this one.  I dont know that Id specifically remember to search it out, but it would be a welcome pull any day.
(bottle). Clear, light amber color. Medium size off white head. Crisp hop aroma. Grassy hop flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Pours a clear copper with a thin white head. Aroma of grassy hops and citrus. Tastes of caramel malt, citrus and grassy hops and some grains. Bitter hop finish and medium carbonation. Pretty tasty brew overall.
on tap @brewery-pours a thin white head and cloudy gold color.  Aroma is sweet grain.  Taste is sweet grain, some hops with bitterness.  OK carbonation.

This light copper beer poured with a decent off-white head and a marvelous floral aroma. There is a restrained caramel malt flavor with a pleasant hop bitterness. This is a well-balance beer that is tasty and easy to drink.
This has the sweet aroma described. The flavor reminds me of British Style IPAs, just as described being a British-style ale. There is a subtle sweetness from the hops as well.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2009 1. Sampler at the Boulder Beer Company, Boulder 10/10/2007
Hop aroma. Golden coloured slightly pale fruity and hoppy with some dryness and bitterness in a crisp finish.
2. From the Jug at the Boulder Beer Company 08/10/2008
Hop aroma. White head. Golden coloured fruity and hoppy pine with a crisp and slightly dry bitter malt finish.
3. On Tap at the Boulder Beer Company, Boulder 23/09/2009
Creamy head. Golden coloured very smooth on the palate and hoppy with a little bitterness in a malt finish.
Poured amber with white head. Aroma of citrus and candy. Flavor was the same. Good balance.

I was really looking forward to sampling this beer on draft, but I was unfortuntely a little disappointed upon tasting it.  It poured a dark golden color with a generous amout of lacing left around the glass.  The aroma wasnt much to write home about, with an average amount of hops, earth and caramel malt.  The body was light and quasi-bland.  There really wasnt much in the body to speak of.  The flavors were pretty much bland and uninteresting.  The finish featured a bit of spicy hoppiness, but not much else.  The Cold Hop was definitely a disappointment.

Light coppery color with a beige head that leaves lacing. Really nice citrus smell. Taste is full of citrus and hops. Medium bodied. Tastes like an IPA more or less. Pretty good, but nothing that is really unique.

Bottle  Pours a clear golden with a white head.  The head has average staying power.  The lacing is okay.  Has a citrus aroma.  Has a good carbonation.
The flavor is very dry.  Has a decent amout of hops but is muted.   Has medium body.  The texture is watery.  The finish is okay.  This is an okay beer.  Lacks the punch I hpoed for, but not bad.

copper in color with a one inch white sand head. bright tropical fruit aroma. grapefruit mango and lemon all present as a result of the dry hopping. faint caramel malt is also noted. fresh hoppy start is bright and flavorful. then it fades to a sweet grainy middle. it concludes with a lightly floral and somewhat spruce/pine finish. fairly evenly divided between hops and malt. more dry hop on the finish. could have used a little more umph on the finish.
Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA. This one may have sat in the fridge to long. The hops were a bit muted. Citurs hops dominated this beer with just a little bit of a malt finish.

Poured to a hazy ornage with medium thick off-white head that lingered well and left good lacing. Nose was a citrusy hop (mostly lemons and grapefruit) offset by a hint of malty dark fruit. Mouthfeel was full and a tad biting, but agian offfset by the sweet smoothness of the malt. Taste followed the nose, with a bit of floral thrown in. This well rounded beer finished strong with a perfect mix of the hoppy bitterness and the sweet warmth of the malt.
Golden in color with white head.  Leaves little silking down glass.  Great smell and taste of hops.  Wonderful overall brew.

12oz bottle poured into pint glass - golden orange with a slight haze and medium white foamy head.  Smell is mild hops, sweet iced tea.  Flavor is sweet caramel malt, butterscotch, with hop bitterness in the finish, not overpowering.  Very drinkable, nothing groundbreaking.

Thanks to kevin at grape and gourmet in virgina bech for recommending this beer

OK I do not prefer english style hopped ales but I figured since it was being recommended I would give it a shot

Looks - its a hazy, cloudy yyellowish orange. Almost looks like a lass of piss after a heavy drinking night.

Aroma - I get some grapefruit, but primarily orange and tangerine nose on this. Its also really mild nose.

Mouthfeel - medium bodied, light citrus upfront then the little bit of bitter that it has comes through on the back end.

Drinkability - This beer is a descent beer which I think it may fall under a more hoppy beer than a regular english style ipa would. the ibus I am sure is up there with a strong pale ale or ipa.
I am glad I got a chance to try this beer,

Serving type: bottle

Real nice, an English style with an American twist (up the hop count, perhaps use American variety hops)

Decent looking dark yellow / light amber, head dissipates quick though and little lacing.  Very nice nose, quite citrusy, but there is toffee in there too.    Very nice balance in the mouth, sweet, bitter, bubbly, velvety at times yet gruff at others.  I enjoyed this.
Orange cloudy pour, light white head. Caramel malt with light, foral, citrus hops. Malty flavor with a bit of hops. Floral, herbal, very english. But, that doesnt necessarily make it that good.

pours hazy orange with medium white head. aroma is both floral hops and citrus. there is also a nice malt/fruity sweetness. drinks with a bitter bite upfront leading to a citrus kiss with some fruits and a nice malt sweetness finishes. crisp and clean with short lingering floral hop taste.

Sampled on 4/8/2009. This English Ale/IPA pours a slightly cloudy medium orange gold color from a 12 oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet, citrus and earthy. A medium bodied ale. The malts are caramel and fruity. The hops are floral and herbal. Nice balance. Lively carbonation. A very drinkable session beer. I am not quite sure just where this beer would fit style wise. Its not really a Pale Ale or IPA and its not really a Strong Ale. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Hazy orange-amber body with a thin white head that quickly goes away.  Sweet floral, citrus, and pine aroma - very nice.  Smooth and light on the palate with moderate-high carbonation.  The flavor one ups the aroma.  Remarkably delicious brew with the sweetness of caramel, raw honey, and sugared grapefruit fading to just a slightly bitter pine, earthy hops finish.  A downright great beer.

12 oz bottle. Im normally a roasted malt maniac but this beer was ridonckulous. Pours a beautiful hazy gold with a thick frothy white head. Aroma is a beautiful floral hop, galangal, pine and resin medley. Flavor reminds me of whole grain toast with fresh raw honey. Beautifully rounded out with the perfect balance of hops. The balance from the front of the palate to the finish is perfect. I couldnt imagine a better session beer. Too bad ABV isnt lower.

22oz bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a massive frothy light tan head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and floral with slight malty notes, light citrus, hops and grapefruit, and hints of honey and caramel. Flavor is sweet and floral as well with notes of citrus, grapefruit, hops, honey, caramel and hints of spice. Generally light body with a floral hop finish.

Pour from the bottle.  Pour produced a grain colored, clear body topped by a small head of white foam.  Hops and grapefruit on the nose.  Flavor is bitter, as expected with a moderately dry finish.  Palate matched the aroma with plenty of hops and grapefruit notes
Slight hoppy aroma. Reddish-brown in color with a white head. Nice balance of hops and malt. Left a nice lace on the glass. I would consider this a good beer to have over again.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy dark gold with a one finger white head that leaves nice lacing.  The nose is malt and light citrus hops.  The taste toffee, sweet citrus and earthy hops with some pine bite in the finish.  Medium body.  Decent stuff.
Crushed with Jakebra. Yet another.  Nose is better on this one.  Good hoppiness and caramel sweetness.  Flavor isnt quite as nice, and it finishes a little musty and cloying.  Still pretty solid.

Sampled from bottle en route to OHare, a lightly hazy amber color. Aroma of floral hops, citrus, caramel, and toast. Taste of caramel, citrus fruits, grass, toasted malt, and a dry, lightly hoppy finish.

22 oz bottle, via EDA.  Pours a sligtly cloudy amber body with a fairly minimal off-white head that quickly vanished.  Kind of an odd aroma, theres a bit of a metallic note, a little bit of oxidation, some noticeable alcohol, very light hoppiness and some biscuity malt.  This is just lightly bitter with a bit of cardboard oxidation, some slightly husky and toasted malts, and a rather short and abrupt finish that has a bit of an alcoholic kick that doesnt help things.  Mouthfeel is fairly lifeless with light fizzy soft carbonation.  A bit of malty stickiness on the back end.  Overall, this seemed like maybe it was a bit over the hill and on the way down.

A british style ale that bites like an IPA but with a less straightforward flavor profile. Unlike most "hop head" ales, this beer offers more than just spicy bitterness. There is a subtile creamy sweetness, a nutty flavor and a warmth, plus the big hopy flavors that so many American microbrew fans love.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 Dont know why its rating isnt in the 4s or higher Im mainly a malt profile drinker with occasional hop tendencies but this has to be my favorite hoppy beer. Great bitterness with just the right amount of sweetness to clean you palette quick enough leaving you aching for another drink, but as said before take heed of the ABv because in taste youd have no idea it was as high as it is. A good session beer......Beginning of re-rate. Not really re-rate but just wanted to comment that the abv was lowerd from 8 to 6.5%.
Poured a yellow hazy,spicy with citrus hints.very easy to drink,very enjoyable.

honey colored with a thin white head and minimal lacing.  aroma is spicy and citrusy with hints of spruce and grapefruit.  hops are immediately evident in the flavor with huge grapefruit that lingers on for sometime into a very dry yet thin finish.

Pleasant surprise. Bought on a whim at a local shop after having a wonderful hugely hoppy microbrew while on vacation. A refreshing change my usual malty preferences. Fresh, floral and earthy/grassy hops with a hint of sweetness that keeps the bitterness from staying with you long.

Pours a slightly hazy amber with a thin head that leaves minimal lacing... Creamy aroma of caramel and piney hops.... Taste is again a bit sweet with notes of piney hops... Almost thin watery like finish led me to believe this beer was a bit low alcohol wise and a good option for a sessionable beer... Higher ABV actually drops this down a bit for me...

what a well balanced brew! pours a clear yellow that belies how potent and excellent this brew is.  after the lager like color, the aroma opens up to wonderful toffee malt, it smells syrupy but the mouthfeel is perfectly quick. the flavor is of hops, but without any citrus or other american notes. and of course the malt rides through, strong as ever.  it stays balanced but at the last minute my tounge sizzles just a bit from subtle bitterness, the hops get the final word!

Attractive hazy golden pour with a fluffy white head.  Nose of floral, earthy hops and lightly roasted caramel malt.   Flavor is fairly straight-forward...floral, earthy hop bite on top of the caramel/toffee malt sweetness.  Really surprised at the ABV...seemed more restrained than that.
Pours hazy golden brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and grapefruit like hops.  Taste is bittersweet bready malt and citrusy hops, with a nice bitter finish.  Pretty good.

Slightly hazy amber pour with thin white head. Aroma of floral hops and dish soap. Flavor was sweet malts, earthy hops, orange, dough and a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied with a nice complex flavor. I wish I had another one because of the complexity of flavors. Nice brew.

Bottle. Hazy amber body with a small, frothy off-white head that disappears. Light aroma of toasted grain and flowers with a hint of dough and a slight whiff of amonia. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter, but it finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, lively carbonation and a smooth texture that turns thick, chewy. Grainy/husky taste thats not very clean.

Pours a nice hazy honey amber with a 2 finger creamy white head that has good retention. Aroma is floral and citrus hops, caramel, toffee, a hint of sweet grain and nice toasty honey coated bicuit. Flavor is mandarin orange, a little floury biscuit, white raisins, honey, earthy wood like flavor, caramel, and fresh toffee. Finish is mildly bitter but mostly floral hops and a good amount of lasting sweetness that leads to a blood orange aftertaste. Body is medium with a good level of carbonation, a good bite and a sweet slightly sticky finish.

British Style Ale?  Not sure where they got that idea, but definitely a good solid IPA.  I would have to say that this is my favorite from Boulder Beer.  It has the most floral taste and widest palate of any that I have tasted.  Head is on the thinner side, and pure white.  Carbonation is good.  Unfiltered beer.  Orange peel and slight apricot dominate the smell of this one.  Great beer but overall slightly thin on the bouquet.

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a one finer creamy offwhite head. The nose is citrusy, fresh pungent, earhty hops, malty background. The flavor has a mild earhty bitterness, herbal hops, mild diacteyl, earthy malt character. The palate has a nice mild bitterness with a good balancing sweetness.

Bottle from Sams. I seem to rate right behind Jamie these days.  Deep golden hazy pour with quickly diminishing white head.  Slightly overcarbonated body. Biscuity malt and mild grassy hops on the nose with a touch of stronger resiny hops behind it. Also, a fruitiness that makes me think of grape juice. A bit sweet overall, but very drinkable and quite pleasant.  Highly sessionable.

This would be a straight forward english ale if it was not for the hint of citrus and slightly stronger alcohol presence. Amber, thin head. Grass, caramel, and citrus. Malty up front, hoppy at the back. Works better when drinking absent mindedly at a party than it does when you try and analyze it too much. Sessionable in an American way.
Clear amber pour thin off white head. Aroma dominated by grassy notes.  Sweet english malts up front with a grassy finish

pours a semi-clear amber-orange with a small white head, and good lacing.

smell is faint, caramel, hops, and some malt.

taste is a bit watery, malt, hops, touch of citrus, grass, and a touch of caramel, ends a little bitter.
Bottle. Pretty meh overall.  Does stay true to the style though--very English in malt and hop characteristics. Very grassy overall, maybe a bit too much.

Pours orange with a fluffy white head. This is a very dry ale, typical of the style but with a very solid bitter hop flavor on the back nine. Nice piney smell as well and some decent malt flavor as well. I liked this one a lot more than I thought I would.
22 oz bomber Pours copper with thin white head More of an English IPA than an English Strong Ale Malt profile is slightly sweet with a tart kick ending on a grassy hoppy note.
This hazy gold pour has a frothy white head.  It smells of hops and pine.  Bitter yet smooth and balanced.  Overall a solid drinkable beer.

12 oz. Cloudy, burnt orange with a creamy one-finger head that endures. Earthy tea leaf, woody hop, toasted bread and caramel aromas. Flavor is a very nice blend of the same with a citrus, resin, and mildly peppery wood finish. Toasted nut and cocoa flavors begin to develop after a few tastes. Medium body is smoothly carbonated, lightly hop-tingly, and has a crisp dry finish.
Pours amber-orange with an average frothy white head-good laciing. Aroma of perfume, pine and grapefruit. Lightly sweet-moderate bitterness with some breadiness. Clean dry finish.

Orange pour with off white head and lace. Semi sweet aroma of malt and medium evergreen hops. Malty and semi sweet malt with a medium light bitter and an hint of vanilla. Medium bodied a tad fizzy on carbonation. Pretty good beer.

12oz bottle. Pours clear orange with white head. Aroma is floral hops, citrus and caramel malt. Flavor is hops, citrus, caramel, light fruit, bread and some earthyness. Kind of bland for an IPA, but does match british style. Solid brew.

Poured a cloudy orange with a white head.  Aroma of caramel malt and a little hops.  Dry palate with the initial flavors being pretty woodsy and earthy with dominant hops and malt behind all that.  Finished hoppy with a dry bitterness that’s well balanced.

Trade with FlssmrBrewAlum, 12 oz bottle. Nice beery smell when I pop the cap, heavy on malts. Pours a somewhat amber and hazy pale ale color, very little head, but I did pour more slowly down the side than usual. A deep smell has suggestions of an antique pine drawer. Totally silly, but that’s what comes to mind. Taste is a little thick in texture, but not syrupy. One of the few "extreme" pale ales where the malt actually beats down any amped up hop load. Some nutty malt sweetness, a backing of orange, slight show of grass and vanilla. A fine beer overall.
Hazy moderate with a thin head and some light lacing. Hop scent with a deep malt base. I get a hint of smoke in a woodsy beer with a moderate (for US) hop profile. Hoppier than a UK version.

Another hoppy treat from Boulder!  My first impression off the tap at the Brewery, during the tour, was that this was certainly a tasty creation with lots of flavor and a great fruity aroma.  Its a little watery to be one of my favorites but my love of hops make this a great driniking beer for me.  Bought a 6er on the way out the door.
Draught at the taphouse at Denver Airport. Cloudy golden - white head. High fresh hoppy, wet grass, fresh grass, light malty, fruity, light sweetness, caramel, peach, grape. Nice.

Pours an orange color with I’d say an average sized head. The aroma is very floral and herbal. This has a real nice, well balanced, hop/malt combo. The malts are bready and biscuity with perhaps some caramel too. The hops are very floral with tropical fruit. This is pretty good. A real nice surprise and better than the decent session brew I thought I might be getting.

bottle. first impression I smelled it out of the bottle and thought it smelled kind of funny, then I poured it and everything changed. I thought it smelled like an americian version of a bitter. citrusy and bright, and as it opened up it just got better. I only bought two bottles and wish I had bought more. A must try for fans of bitters or ESBs.

Pours orange, white head.
Aroma, hoppy floral/piney, yeasty (moldy) sweet and caramel.
Taste, some caramel malts with nice bitter hoppiness (floral and piney)
Some flating sediments and fruity (graperfruit) hints.

Pours a light golden color with a very nice inch of pillowy white head.  Smell is subtle hops.  Taste is mellow hops, with a bit of mild bitterness.  This is a decent beer, just doesn’t seem to come together.  Really smooth and seems quite sessionable, but at 6.5% this one will catch up with you.  Decent, but nothing extraordinary.

Bomber bought in Wyoming. Pours a orange color with a medium white head and lots of lacing. The aroma is full of hops; grapefruit and citrus notes. The taste was very very smooth; loads of hoppy citrus, very fresh and nice. A bit of caramel malt also. Very tasty. I think this one is a bit underrated, a very nice quaffable beer.

The first beer of our epic GABF trip to denver! On tap at the Boulder Bar in the Denver airport, enjoyed while we waited for the rest of the group to arrive. Clear orange amber, aroma of toffee and vague fruits. Lots of resinous and citrus hop character-- I thought this was an IPA until I saw it here! Very good, but not in any way english-style.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Grass, citrus, and caramel aroma notes.  Golden amber with white head.  Grass, citrus, and mild caramel flavour notes.  Full-bodied with medium bitter finish.

Draught at the brewpub.
Clear amber coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, grass and grape fruits.
Fruity flavour of hops, grass and grape frruits with notes of eucalyptus.
Hoppy finish.

Light amber, nice head, a bit hazy, attractive.  Great nose of grapefruit, floral, and earthy hops.  Flavor is initially a floral and earthy hop profile, moving into a very nice sweet biscuity malt finish.  Very enjoyable, complex, but easy drinking.  I really liked this one, it is deserving of more love.

Beautiful amber pour with a thin head and minimal lacing. Nose is floral and grapefruit, with a bit of pine. Taste was earthy and citrus. Nice hops. Mouthfeel was moderately oily and the finish carried on with citrus and hop bitterness.

Bottle. Hazy orange-amber pour with a small off-white head resting upon it. Nose is hoppy and citrusy with sweet malts, fresh fruit, and pine.Taste is equally hoppy and vibrant. Lots of citrus fruit flavors, pine needles, hop resins and sweet malts. Light hint of toffee as well. Body is medium with a creamy carbonation and some oily slickness. Ends with more citrus fruits, pine, hop oils, grapefruit juice, and sweet malts. Very tasty!
Pours amber with a off white foamy head. Great hop flavor. Have another? Yes I shall.
Draft. This was a delicious beer with a wonderful hoppy taste to it. This here is a must try. One of my favorites.
12 oz. bottle pour. Wonderful hoppy aroma, nice off-white head. Nice hoppy bitterness, with a touch of malt. Perhaps a bit over-hopped, but I like it.

Pours orange amber into a shaker.  Fizzy off-white head pancakes as it recedes.  Deep pine and resin aromas. Crisp with citrus (orange and grapefruit) from front to back. Dry lasting grapefruit and orange finish.

12-ounce brown bottle in Albuquerque. Amber color, creamy white head and lace. Intense hoppy aroma. Medium body, pronounced hop flavor and bitterness. Subtle malt flavor, late alcohol notes. Even dry/sweet flavor balance. Not well-balanced, but likely to appeal to hop-heads.
Bottle, #404   Hazy golden pour with small head. Light floral hop aroma. Great hoppy flavor too. Good brew overall.

(bottle) Hazy orange body and medium off-white head with peaks and lacing. Wonderfully floral, fruity and hoppy aroma - sweet, fresh grapefruit. Light bodied, and tingly carbonation. Flavor is sweet, but dries up somewhat on the way back. Lots of fruit, some caramel.

Poured a light amber hue, forming decent eggshell white foamy head.  Aroma of pine resins, passion fruit and grapefruit; very oily and fresh; lacks a bit of density.  The flavour however is smoother and more refreshing than I was expecting for a "cold hop" type beer. Flavors of orange juice, pine needles and a bit of a toffee earthiness lead off, smoothing it to a dry, perhaps somewhat one-dimensional finish.  I mean, it was ok to drink, had a bit of character, but in the end it was slightly dull.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle.  Hazy, light amber color.  Large, frothy, off white head.  Malty aroma.  Sweet flavor with a dash of earthy hops.  Metallic taste at the end.

12 oz bottle, light golden pour.  Smells like someone jammed a cascade hop leaf up my nose.  Taste follows as expected; hoppy, cascade all the way.  Good but pretty one-dimensional.  I think I just burped up a leaf.

Nice orange color with a large, frothy and lasting white head.  Aroma is mostly hoppy with some really fresh citrus notes.  Medium body, slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Medium carbonation but there is some hop prickliness that accentuates it.  More citrusy hops with very faint caramel.   Malt becomes evident towards the finish and lends a nice, very light, sweetness.  Not a hint of the abv.  This brew is fantastic.

Thanks to Beer_Hawk for sharing this one at Illinismitty’s tasting.
Hazy orange/gold with a fleeting off-white head.
Floral citrus hop aroma.
Chalky palate with the citrus hops coming in for a reprise of the aroma in flavor form.
Nice balance.
[Bottle] Pours a light caramel with a medium off white head. Aroma is sauerkraut, green tea, and citrus. Flavor is nice hops. Tastes a little past its prime. Grassy, wierd lingering aftertaste.

Sampled this beer poured from chilled bottle into a pint glass. Had a two-finger head and was amber in color. I enjoyed the aroma which had hints of citrus and pine. The flavor was solid but seemed to be lacking in fullness. The body seemed lighter than expected. Overall, an enjoyable beer that went down easy.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2009 bottle from 3 Sons.  Cloudy light amber in color, not much head or lacing.  Fragrant but not the usual floral hops, and different with a funky creamy hop taste, a little sour background and very nice finish. Distinct taste of catawba grapes

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2008 dud fuckin bomber on a shit poor day. floaties, harsh like cheap sourmash used to be malty and stingy bitter. maybe an english ale from back when they were covered in soot. color of light clay pot. grains oh yeah grains for sure! looks like a good white head......what the hell it couldnt kill me huh?

Pours a clear golden with a small off white head. Aroma is medium sweet with grapefruit, peach, floral and light bread. Flavor is grapefruit, peach, caramel and light bread. Light to medium bodied, thin texture. I really thought this was a very nice beer and I cannot understand what it is doing in the Strong Ale category.

Bottle. Poured a hazy orange with an off-white head that left light lacing. Aroma of caramel, molasses, butter, and a light hop background. The flavor finds caramel with a light nut and chocolate and a hoppy background. Medium body and medium bitterness. Not bad!

Bottle from the other Steve who likes cornholing.   Pours out an orange color with a white head on it.
