Smell is fruity with some nice light hoppy smells, some citrus, some grass, and a nice sweetness.  Interesting smell.  Taste is smooth and dominated by malts without much of the hop presence noted.  Smooth and drinkable, a pretty interesting beer here.  I wasnt expecting this one.

12 oz bottle. Clear gold with a nice, tight white head. Lots of pine and earth in the nose, with white grapefruit and caramel. Mild caramel spine is fleshed out with piney woodiness and dry grapefruit and nectarine. Clean finish, very drinkable.

pours a nice orangish-copper colour with a tight medium off white head.
Aroma is delicious caramel maltiness and a floral hop.
Flavour is a little lighter than expected.
Nice medium malt body. I thought it was going to taste hoppier but the body is firm yet smooth maltiness with a very clean finish. Super smooth and drinkable. A very nice strong ale.

First good beer at the Oxidationfest Tasting at illinsmitty’s, thanks BeerHawk!  Golden amber pour with ring of off-white head.  Deceptively malty aroma, sweet, raisins, figs, some plum.   However, the flavor leans heavily toward the hoppy, somewhat floral.  Nicely balanced with a hop finish.  Medium body and medium low carb.

Bottle from Beer_Hawk. Pours orange amber with an off white head. Lighter side of medium bodied. Citrusy and pale malt nose. Toffee malt and citrusy flavors, with a moderate bitterness and slight acidity. Nicely attenuated.

12 oz bottle from  a 6-pack from Binny’s (South Loop, Chicago, IL). Pours an interesting fiery orangish hue with a substantial offwhite head that dissipates pretty quickly to a small film. Aromas are floral hoppiness, pink gumball-like candy (Or Bazooka Joe!), and a touch of citrus zest. Initial taste is similar, floral hoppy taste with a very sweet balancing, almost candy like. This beer tastes strikingly similar to Gumballhead in profile (Minus the wheat), but more powerful and maybe a tad cloying. Finishes a bit watery and is a fairly light to light medium bodied brew overall, but clean and without too much of a messy sweetness like one might expect. I actually liked this brew. Cheers!
A brown ale that almost tastes a bit dusty. Sweet grains and floral hop. The Looking Glass Series are generally superb.

Intense pine and sugary lemons on the nose.  Light amber color, slight haze, soapy head.  smooth candied malt sweetness, gentle but pronounced bitterness.  Full body,  carbonations is delicate, but strong, very smooth finish.  Very well-put together beer, has candy-like sweetness with excellent balance.  My lasting  impression is that this was hopped with candied hop cones!

lets just face it: im ethnocentric when it comes to my beers. ive never vowed myself to patriotism in any arena except craft ales. and this here cold hop - though made by my dear friends there at boulder brewing company in smack-dab colorado, USA - is a british ale. so i come to it with curled-knuckled racist resistance - all the equivalent angst of the sex pistols God-blessing the queen and what the piss have you. but, unlike the clash, i am not so bored with the USA style ales: we make them big and adventurous and unsafe. this cold hop is typically british, but holstered up with a double dose of hop flavor - lots of flowers and nuts here. lots of dry aftertastes and leather booted pageantry. im proud of my dear friends at boulder for achieving such a beer - but i cant be bothered to drink much of it. give me hazed. give me mojo. bollocks - give me singletrack copper. but dont give me cold hop. give this to the rolling stones and the clandestined.

Dark copper color with heavy, blanketing lacing above a moderately sized head. Looks great and smells great too due to a prominent floral hop presence. Fruity with some sweet caramel. Mildly sweet and bitter with a creamy body. This beer awakened my taste buds. Great balance from malt flavors of bread, caramel, and nuts. Citrus and flowery hops counter the hops in great form. A very tasty pale ale.

Bottle.  Poured a clear gold color with a huge off white head.  Aroma of floral and grassy hops with a fruity note.  Flavor is sweet malt with a floral ending.  Good beer.  Medium bodied with mild/high carbonation.

a clear orange with little lacing under a large yellowish creamy head.  juicy peach hop aroma with touches of spicy caramel malt.  flavor is quite hoppy for an english style beer with lots of peach syrup, citrus and spruce sprigs.  bready caramel malts provide decent balance.  sweet candyish finish.  medium bodied.  very sweet.
Bottle.  Clear, dark golden pour with no head.  Aroma of hops, both herbal and citrus.  Similar flavor with some malty sweetness and a touch of grassiness.
Floral and grassy aroma with a nice flavor that is very similar. A nice twist on the english IPA. Well done.
Got this at my local shop at a big close out price.  Apricot pour leads to a a nice hop aroma with some great malts.  Flavor follows suit.
very enjoyable with the flowery hop nose leading to a fruity start immediately mellowing into a smooth, if hoppy, english ale. a drinker.

12 ounce bottle, the aroma is very, very hoppy. It smells tasty. It’s a dark golden color with a nice off white head. The taste is   grassy hops with some underlying malt but not very much. Kind of sweet finish, Good aftertaste. I’m not sure what English Strong Ales are but this tastes a lot like an IPA to me
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Don’t see how this is a "British style ale".   Its tatses exactly like an American style IPA, and not a good one - very sticky for a mere 6.5%.
bottle.  light copper. clarity.  foamy head leaves lacing.  earthy malts, cut grass, light malt aroma.  grainy, earthy hops light.  thin on flavor.  light sweetness in malts.

Copper-colored pour with an slight orange hue.  1/2-inch off-white head that laced the inside of the glass.  Citrus, grassiness, and pine on the nose.  Palate is right down the middle...refreshing.  Citrus on the forefront, malt sweetness and somewhat tea-like.  Good beer and great price.
12oz bottle. Pours clear amber in color with thin white head. Aroma sweet and citrus hops. Taste citrus hops and spicey with bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle from Wine Warehouse. Amber pour with a medium head and good lacing. Very spicy and leafy hop aroma with a slight sweetness. Bitter leafy hop taste with a caramel and grain finish. Slightly off balanced.

12oz.  Meh, if there ever was a good effort but ultimately disjointed brew, this is it.  A pretty pour of deep golden slightly hazy goodness topped but a fleeting white head.  Nose had me do a doubletake, I kept getting steamed broccoli.  After tasting, I kept getting the same kind of malt/grain/hop combo that kept making me think steamed broccoli.  Maybe this kind of ruined it for me, has the body and components of a worthwhile brew I’m just not digging what it tastes like.

As the great reviewer Randy Jackson said "I’m not feelin it dawg." Had no head, had little aroma, and the taste was of lemon and grains. Not sure if I got an off bottle, but as it stands, I’d pass on the next one.

Hazy dark orange-burnt sienna with rich creamy beige head and particulates in the glass. Smells like cold rocks after a rainstorm. Orchard fruits--ripe apple and pear. Flowers. Smells very American. Great silky palate, quaffable. Mellow, smooth, nice hop but not a lot of Brit references in the malt or hop. Malts are slightly metallic and apple-like. Hops are well-integrated. Not as English as it professes to be but refreshing and good.

Amber, cloudy, with a loose head.  Earthy nose with light citrus.  Earthy taste, again with c-hop woodiness.  Light, refreshing.  Some light toast, caramel.  Quite clean, finishing dry.  Not bad, definitely not English, but a tasty brew.

Cloudy orange with a thin off-white head, quickly dissipating.  Aroma of citrus, bread, sweet malts and floral hops.  Taste of floral hops, fruit, caramel, citrus and vegetal notes.  Body is grainy and oily.

Draft at the brewpub. A hazy amber beer with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet matly with notes of caremel as well as light notes of fruit. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and alcohol, leading to a dry bitter finish. NW and NZ hops and 6.5% ABV in an English Style ale - I don’t get it.

Aroma is malt, and orangey hops, opague orange, a tiny white head. Flavour is a rich malt, good west coast hops bang.  Medium bodied, very well balanced, great mouthfeel. Lovely little beer. Thanks Torontoblue.
Fruity and floral with a strong caramel and bready/toasty malt backbone.  Not overly hopped.  Seems much more American than Englsih.  Refreshing.

nice fruity aroma
medium extra condensed white foamy head
excellent toasted malt taste with light hopping and a slight caramel/brown sugar aftertaste
a very refreshing change from the normal american microbrew hop-bombs!

Poured hazy brown/orange with a modest white head. Aroma is floral with a little spice. Flavor is a well balanced bitter. Mouthfeel is modest with a non-aggressive flavor that makes this very drinkable. Good, not great. A good session beer.

THOUGHTS: It definitely tasted British, but with an American twist. Pretty nice beer with nice balance.
TECHNiCAL: Bottle. Poured a medium, brownish orange that glowed amber when held to the light with medium-sized body particles of an average density and a small, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was moderate cereal, molasses and carmel malt, moderate flowery hops, light barnyard and earthy yeast, toffee and a little bit of spices. The initial flavor was light to moderately sweet and lightly acid; while the finish was moderate to heavily sweet, lightly acidic and moderately bitter with an average duration. There was caramel and cereal, then some floral and a little metallic hops and some earthiness. The light to medium body was a little dry at the end with kind of soft, but fizzy on the lips carbonation and a moderate astringent and slight metallic finish.

12oz bottle. Pours pale caramel color, capped with a small white head. Appealing aroma, with notes of grapefruit, rye, apricot, and caramel. Earthy, piney hops define the flavor, with notes of rye, caramel, and grain. Very nice effort from Boulder.
Bottle.  Poured Amber gold with a lasting white head.  Aroma that began sour, and turned hoppy.  Medium body and flavour with a good, light finish
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle. Pours orange with a beige head. Floral/earthy/herbal aroma with a bit of caramel malt. Medium body. Flavor is again floral and earthy hops with a bit of caramel malt. Not bad.

Bottle.  Big, hoppy, resinous, caramel- and lychee-soaked nose, very fresh and bready with some citrus.  Hazy amber-copper pour with a yellow-tinged creamy beige head.  Light-bodied and only mildly bitter.  Very smooth body.  Nice musty hop funk.  Deep, dark earth and caramel, with he resin and citrus seemingly disappeared.  A good, slightly sweet malt base with an herbal note, and some toasted grain and light woody pine.  I was expecting something of a hop bomb actually, if the abv were a bit lower, Id call this an very good (and underrated) English session, with just enough nuance to be called classy.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2008 Very fragrant, reminiscent of the aroma of a Double IPA or a fresh-hop harvest ale.  Flavor has sweetness and body is much like a sticky resinous hop-bombing IxPA.  The hop character is very played up in pretty much every aspect except for flavor, which is medium-strong-hoppy by mainstream standards.  Definitely worth coming back to, especially at the modest price.  I recommend this, and the RB average has dropped the ball on this somewhat.  Something of this quality would get around a 3.7 RB average in a true, fair blind tasting.

12oz bottle served in an English pint glass. Didnt realize it was bottle conditioned and ended up pouring a good deal of sediment into the glass. Pours cloudy (oops) amber with a generous head. Smells of caramel, biscuit, and grass. Sweet malts balanced by grassy, herbal hops. Quite nice actually, I wasnt really expecting too much from this. The finish has a nice amount of hops and lasts for quite awhile. Pretty good.

Pour is hazed bright amber with a tight bubbled tan head...smell is nicely hoppy with  grapefruit and some caramel numbers...taste is faintly sweet at first with a subtle grapefruit and pine bitterness....something a little stale in the finish...good though....

This beer had everything I was looking for and more. Pours orangeish body with a thin white head that sticks around to the end. It leaves tree ring like lacing all the way down the glass. it has aromas of caramel, hops, and spice. The mouthfeel is realitively light, with little sprits of fruit jumping about. overall i thought it was awesome.

(n) Decent brew from boulder, a big-ish English style ipa, maybe?.  Pours a clear golden straw color with a decent head.  Smells of toasted bread and dank floral hops.  Taste is very well balanced, good matching of hops and malt.  Astringent bitterness up front, some grainy biscuit bread malt flavors, and a middling amount of floral, resinous hops.  Decent on the palate- relatively easy drinking, while staying full flavored.
Bottle.  Pours a golden amber body with a thin head.  Aroma is sweet malt, floral hops, some light fruit.  A good amount of hoppy bitterness throughout this one. not bad.

Hazy orange with large white head.  Aroma is worty with grape nuts and earthy caramel tones that mingle with the grapefruity hops. Taste is way off and band-aidy, with a hollow metallic mouthfeel.  Not sure what the brewer was shooting for, but I would guess that this is not it.  $3/22oz

A simple beer, and likely enough for avowed hop heads.  I am less convinced, though the stores price makes it a certain acquisition.  The pour quickly produces a lumpy though thin and light head.  The body is a cloudy amber - a standard paint job in the beer world.  The aroma certainly elicits hops - fresh hops, too.  Actually, imagine that when you win the big game, instead of having a barrel of gatorade dumped on you, its a barrel of freshly harvested hops.  Not bad for most, but very bad for those of us that find purified hop astringency to be less than pleasant.  Tongue wrenching.  This hops is solidly dedicated to that bitter aspect, no counterbalanced grain of sugar here.  Nosing around the flavor one can find a slight nuttiness, and maybe a whisper of honey, but one wrong move and BOOM, like a landmine you hit another patch of spicy hops.  What I found most interesting was that, under these circumstances I typically associate the hops bitterness with grapefruit.  But even that, the fruit, seems to have been forcibly stripped and tossed away, again leaving only the essence of hops bitterness.  It would be magical if it werent so difficult to drink.  Drink at a snails pace, or be ready for taste bud restorative surgery.
A very tasty ale.  Flavors are fresh and crips almost like a marzen in style.  Nice balance of hops and very light fruit.  Pours golden with a frothy white head.

Bottle into English pint glass.  Pours a honey color with a fluffy khaki head.  Lacing is chunky and impressive.  Aroma is fruity flowers, taste is sharp, zingy hops, sweet, toasty malts and a clean, lingering hops finish.  The mouthfeel is tingly and leaves a light coating on the palate.  A nice beer, but not necessarily one I would return to again and again.

Pours with a frothy, initially fat-two-finger thick, light tan colored head into my 25cl tulip glass.  The beer is a lightly hazy, ruddy amber color, but shows a bright, almost clear, copper color when held up to the light.  The aroma is much more malt focused than I was expecting; ample notes of sweet caramelized malt, toasted bread notes, a biscuit maltiness and a sweet grain cookie character are all quite prominent.  This does have some hop character, it just plays a secondary role to the malt; hop driven aromas of currants, a rich earthy spiciness and a light resinous hop character all seem to accentuate the malt character more than jumping out on their own.  This has quite a pleasant aroma, it is just surprisingly malt focused for a beer with the word hop on so prominent a display on its label.

Sweet malt character is the first thing I notice in my first sip, but this is fairly light bodied, though it does have a slightly sticky malt texture to it.  The hops kick in with a resinous, herbal hop flavor and persistent, lightly astringent bitterness.  The hops play more of a role in the flavor than they did in the aroma, but they are still second fiddle to the ample, sticky malt character.  The sweet malt and hop character combines to create a jam-like, berry flavor here.  I do like the finish of this brew as the hop character gets a bit herbal, with a nice floral accent & light bitterness that helps to wash the mouth of the excessive crystal malt.  It is only an attempt, as the hop character really doesnt have a chance of standing up to the malt here; caramelized malt sugars, ample biscuit-like flavors and an astringent grain husk edge that though light, just adds to the crystal malt domination.

The crystal malt notes play a bit too big of a role here, they completely overwhelm the aroma and even make a significant attempt at washing out the flavor of this brew.  Really not all that bad, but if you are sensitive to excessive crystal malt usage this may be a little too much.  Strangely, though the aroma is much more malt dominated than the flavor, it is the flavor where the malt just becomes too excessive.

Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson AZ
Sweet aroma with a light floral hop smell. Hazy orange color with a small white head. Light bitterness in the beginning with a malty finish.

Pours orange-amber with a large off-white head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is quite forward, floral earthy hops.
Taste is closer to a good APA than I expected from the description. Plenty of citrus hops that were the dominant flavor here. A well made tasty beer that I enjoyed. Maybe not the right category though.

12oz bottle.  Pours amber.  Nose is mostly hops, somewhat astringent with some citrus undertones.  Taste is hops, minor citrus.  Seems more like an IPA than strong ale.  I might be rating this a little on the generous side..
Amber color.  Smell of malt, apricots, hops and grass.  Taste of hops, flowers, malt, minor caramel and minor citrus peal.

Bouteille 650ml, courtoisie de Blankboy. De couleur orange ambrée et claire. Nez de houblon moyennement floral, légèrement citrique (pamplemousse)  ainsi quavec des notes herbeuses et résineuses, moyen de fruits (abricots) et malté de caramel sucré. Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse et aux petites notes résineuses.  Moyen goût fruité (abricots, traces dagrumes et de mangues) accompagné dun goût moyennement amer de houblon floral et légèrement citrique (une amertume présente toute la gorgée) ainsi que de notes épicées (poivre) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de caramel légèrement sucré aux petites notes terreuses et rôties ainsi que des notes de biscuits, de pain et de céréales puis en finale lon retrouve un léger regain damertume de houblon plus herbeux (herbe mouillée et notes de thé) et aux faibles notes résineuses ainsi que des traces de légumes bouillis et de noix. Post-goût moyen aux notes sèches, moyennement amer de houblon floral, moyennement herbeux, légèrement citrique et aux notes résineuses ainsi que de faibles notes fruitées (zest dagrumes).
From a bottle poured brown with a fair amount of head.  Nice hoppy flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle. Small ivory head that mostly diminished, next to no lacing, transparent, carbonation observed, and a golden orange hue. Nose was caramel, hoppy, citrus, fruity, and floral. Flavor was caramel, hoppy and citrus. Tingly mouthfeel and medium body. A quaffable brew, nothing totally outstanding about it but worthy of a try IMO.
Golden amber with a small white head.  Aroma is citrusy with a taste of malt and citrus hops.  Nice drinkable ale.

From a 22 oz bottle this poured a nice apricot color with light yellow head that was big and fizzy and left great lacing.  Nose of piney and fruity hops, light malts and a touch of flowers.  Good rich mouthfeel.  Flavor is of fruits and hops, and there is nice long bitter finish. Very enjoyable to drink.

On tap @ BT.  Amber orange in color with a little white head. Malty caramel hoppy aroma. Citrusy earthy hoppy notes.  Malty hoppy sweet flavor. Spicy notes.  Medium bodied. Finish is bitter and spicy. Decent beer. Drinkable.
On tap at BT. Amber orange with a small head. Aroma is blood orange and caramel. Flavor has a nice, dusty hop bite to it to go along with the sweet malt bill. One of the better Boulder beers.

bottle poured an amber in color with a thin white head on the surface and light carbination. aroma has hops spices, grapefruit, sweet malt, and light fruit. mouth feel is medium with active carbination. flavor has nice hops but not as strong as i would have thought, sweet fruit, and some flowery notes. finishes with some bitterness and spicy hops. good brew more like a toned down ipa. became more caramelized as it warmed and overall was a nice drinker.
Bottle: Caramel color, spicy celery hop note. Full-on cheap glycerin, 2-row, medium body. Hoppy tail, light malt, bland and uninspired.
Decent piney hops in aroma from the pour.  Less hops that an IPA but more flavor than a standard APA (which is what i thought it would be classified as)  Drinkable, not outstanding.

22 oz. bottle from Sun Devil Liquors - Pours a hazy amber color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Very light spotty lacing.  Aroma is toasted malt, light floral hops, and light esters.  Flavor is lightly sweetened malt, esters, and a dose of hops.   Medium body.  A decent beer.

aromatic hop burst, mild hop backing. copper hue, cotton fluffy white head. this is what i expect an english bitter to taste like. consistent smooth soft caramel malt foundation allows an earthy swirl of spicy hops.

Muddy apricot pour with a minimal but lasting off white head with good lacing, the predictably hoppy strong ale is rather refreshing and very drinkable.  
Like other reviewers, I also dont understand the cold hop reference.

Tap at the Muddy Pig.  Bright orange; fairly cloudy.  Aroma suggests an expiration date long since passed.  Dry grass, dead flowers, compost, salty cheese, and some mild vinegar heavy tobasco.  Unpleasant and off, but hinting more pleasantly at honey biscuits and cotton candy with a little warmth.  Tastes of crisp autumn leaf, old orange juice, celery salt, and fish oils; full of strangeness, rotting fruits and caramelized white onions.  Prickly in the mouth, tightly wound, and musty; finishes with fresher floral dryness and a bit of nutty oil.  Plenty of iron and aluminum water.  Old.  Will rerate when the mood strikes, but the mood for hosewater and compost air is a bit hard to come by.

Had on-tap at The Blind Tiger in NYC.

Pours a foggy orange amber. Nose is very piney hops with that sweet character to it. Flavor is very hopped, but in a noticeably English style. I feel like it purposefully subdues itself and never gets out of hand, as many American versions of the style might. The hops present themselves and then an earthy bitter tone hits you. Feel has a bit of carbonation to it. The liquid is thick, though it gives a thick, slick, and syrupy texture on the mouth. Overall very good. Definitely one for the hop heads and possibly one for the real ale folks out there too.
Brittish style pale ale, done well but very mediocre.   Slight hop mixed with big malt. Notes of toffee.   Citrus.   Nothing over the top impresive.

The look: clear and coppery, with a big, active head, dwindling with a quickness. 

The smell: bright, fresh, hoppy, plenty of citrus pith, grapefruit and pine...apricot and orange...wide open and wondrous. 

The taste: sweet and tangy, with plenty of jazz and juice. Slips easily off the tongue.
Medium bodied, full of fruity flavor, with just enough hop smack to tickle the tastebuds. Caramel malt adds deliciousness. 

According to the label, they consulted one of Charlie Papazians favorite English IPA recipes, "gave it (their) own twist and (they were) over the moon with the results." My guess is that the twist is American hops...thats what I feel really differentiates this from an English Pale Ale or IPA... 

whats up with the name? "Cold Hop"?Huh? Whats that mean? The opposite of Hot Hop? Anyone know? 

Anyway, it drinks down really nice, but not that amazing of a creation. I could have kept the five bucks. A pleasant sip, nonetheless...

12 oz bottle.  I bought this six pack mostly for my wife ... and Im happy if she drinks most of it.  Pours a clear orange color with a decent sized head that laces down. The hops come out in the nose as floral and grassy with a touch of citrus and toffee.  Toffee/caramel malts with the pine and floral hops that seem to be fading.  This mixture of spice and grass that comes out near the finish gets old really quick.  Not too great.

Clear amber, moderate head with good lacing and retention. Aroma is spicy, and grassy hops, somewhat fruity as well. Caramel backing. Medium bodied, moderate bitterness. Gets better as the bottle empties, but Im still not wild about English IPAs.

Pours dark amber with a mostly receding wispy off-white head. Aroma of resinous English hops, piney, grapefruit, intense Fuggles. Taste is resinous hops, toffee,pine, and sticky fruits. Mouthfeel is full bodied, lightly resinous and sticky with lush carbonation. Not bad, but not impressed.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a slightly hazy softly carbonated light orange brown colored body. The weak aroma was hoppy. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish hoppy aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of malt hops and mild brown malt. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Bottle.  Murky amber with no head.  Aroma was fruity (apricot and grapefruit) and hops.  The taste was not quite as strong or biting.  Still some hoppiness and grapefruit was apparent.  Smooth and tasty on the palate.

Orange gold with a nice head. Spicy floral aroma. Touches of pepper and biscuity English malt. Sweet and biscuity with funky feet bitterness. Seemed stylistically accurate, it was just a little boring.

Nice cloudy orange coloured body with a thinnish white head. Aroma of fresh hops, grass, hay and some more hops - very nice! Light to Medium-bodied; Strong hop flavour of grass and grapefruits noticeable up front, with some apricot flavours and a very nice malt backbone. Aftertaste shows more hops, but arent bittered at all. Overall, a nice offering - not an amazingly hoppy beer, but definitely good for folks that enjoy hops - including myself. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Norms in Vienna, Virginia on 25-December-2007.

bottle - Pours hazy copper with a medium sized head.  Aroma is mostly of pine and citrus hops with a hint of caramel malt.  The flavor is a well balanced mix of sweet malt flavors and pine accented hops.  Its medium bodied and overall a good quaff without being a truly great one.

From a 12 ounce bottle. Deep hazy amber colored with a light khaki head. The aroma is classic grapefruit with roasted peanuts and toffee. The taste is subtle, I love that this one does not slap you in the face with its hops. More subtle. The body is very soft with notes of toffee and light oranges. A silky smooth body make this one go down easy. I had no idea this was 6.5% alcohol. Nicely done.

Bottle.  Aromas are heavy of hoppy pine and citrus and are detectable from across the room.  Color is a darkish amber with about two fingers of head.  On closer inspection, hops are followed up by some caramel malt scents, too.  Flavor is a nice mix of caramel malt and hops that is interesting, but not spectacular.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12 oz bottle pours a hazy coppery orange.  Spicy, hoppy aroma.  Taste is of hops , but not like MOJO or Hazed and Infused.  Grassy, herbal, and piney, with a little malt to balance it our.  A nice beer, I didnt enjoy it as much as I would have a Mojo IPA.  I guess I prefer the over powering citrus hops.

Pours a bronze-orang color, thin head rapidly fades. Aroma is hard to pin down; strong malt background with piney hops. The piney hop come through in the flavor, theres also a light citrus flavor in the mix. A bready malt holds it together. Theres a long-lasting hop after taste. Seems to be a classic English IPA.

12 oz. bottle, pours an opaque golden color with minimal head. Very refreshing citrusy aroma fraught with hops. Flavor is good but the palate is amazingly smooth. Pleasant aftertaste and overally an excellent beer- my favorite so far out of Boulder.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a medium hazy light amber- deep copper with a nice head.  Aroma is tons of tea-hops, grassy, herbal and flowery- with a mild toasty malt backbone- reminded me of Troegs ESB.  Good hop flavor, grass, herbal, tons of nice english hops and a good sweet malt character- crisp and clean finish makes it very easy drinking.

12 oz. Pours a pale orange colour with a medium off-white head that leaves small bits of lacing and fades completely. The aroma is of grapefruit citrus, bready malts, pine and some caramel. The flavour brings a toasted element with some floral hops and and grapefruit citrus again. Medium bodied with a slightly slick mouthfeel with gentle carbonation. This is a very straight forward, typically English brew that is balanced and pleasant, but nothing to actively seek.

22oz bottle. Poured a darker and slightly hazy orange color with a larger sized off white head. Aromas of pine, citrus, biscuit, caramel, and slightly earthy. Tastes of earthiness, caramel, pine, and toasted grains.

Pours a slightly hazed dark orangey amber with a small whitish head that diminished rapidly.  Grainy, biscuity malts, orange juice and lemon zest, floral hoppiness.  Brash hoppiness in the flavor - much more apparent than in the aroma - sharply bitter floral hops with an earthy character, grapefruit rind, young evergreen needles and toasty, caramelized malts add a nice balance.  Full body and prickly carbonation.
On tap at Colllins pub a while back. Dark, hazy amber. The hops are there, but this is definitely an almost over balanced british IPA. Roasted malt with plenty of sweetness. A bit of alcohol.
Poured with a relatively thick head.  Mild hoppy aroma.  The beer is pretty clear and transparent.  Interesting beer.  Just a little bits of hops noted and finishes bitter.

An admirable attempt at reproducing a classic Brit Ale. Pours a slightly hazy amber-orange color under a 1/2" off-white head which gradually fades to a thin spotty film. No lacing is noted as the beer is consumed. Subtle and delicate aromas of flowers, caramel, earth, fresh bread and a touch of orange and lemon are enjoyed. Mouthfeel was clean and fairly light with subtle carbonation; but finished a tad thin. Flavor profile was well balanced and subtle with gentle notes of caramel, biscuits, toffee, spices, flower essence, citrus and herbs. Finishes with a semi-firm crisp hop bitterness balanced with a touch of honey-like sweetness. Seems to me to be about as good as anything the Brits are putting out these days.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 22oz bottle thanks to BeerandBlues2.  Mostly clear amber honey orange colored body.  Nose of sweet clover honey and moist, dank grassy hop cones, with some pineapple and peach fruit notes.   Some tinged and toasted hops, some bready toasty malt notes, some roughness noticed.  Overall quite hoppy, very juicy as well as grassy but not dry at all.  Interesting.

Deep golden/amber beer, thick white head.  Aroma is fairly hoppy.  Earthy and woody with a touch of orange character, a bit of musky/cologne like earthiness.  Quite fresh-smelling.  Flavour is quite nice with some soft toasty malts balanced by earthy/lightly spicy/herbal hops.  Warming brings up a lovely musky/floral aroma.  Good balance, soft bitterness.  Good balance, soft bitterness.  A different take on the IPA, but its tasty.

Big head on harsh pour. Armor is strong citrus/hops very nice but not world class. attack is citrus, perhaps grapefruitish, finish is bitter and long. its rough around the edges but if you want some strong flavors that mostly do the right thing then this is a good beer.

Poured gold with a small head.  Aroma has flowery hops,  good pot,  and lemon.  It has a nice hoppy flavor with just a hint of malty sweetness for balance.  Not nearly as bitter as it smells,  refreshing.

Draft at Which Brew. Golden yellow body with thin head. The aroma is hoppy - citrus, malty. Flavor is sweet malt with a hoppy bite to it. Easily more hoppy than any other "english strong ales" I have ever had.

12oz bottle. thanks jase! copper in color with a one inch white sand head. bright tropical fruit aroma. grapefruit mango and lemon all present as a result of the dry hopping. faint caramel malt is also noted. fresh hoppy start is bright and flavorful. then it fades to a sweet grainy middle. it concludes with a lightly floral and somewhat spruce/pine finish. fairly evenly divided between hops and malt. more dry hop on the finish. could have used a little more umph on the finish.

Pour orange / copper with a small light beige head.  The aroma has woody earthy hops, some prominent sweetness and some mild caramel malt.  Medium rough body with fairly sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with sweet caramel malt, light cotton candy and some spicy hops.  The finish has the woody earthy hops coming to the front.  A decent beer.

Pour is a orange with a small white head.  Aroma is a very nice hop and malt combo with a nice spice coming through.  Flavor is very herbal and heavy.  Finish is earthy and bitter. A nice take on the style and one you should seek out.

A unique take on a British style IPA, given the the cold hopping and creaminess. A tad of toastiness in the aroma and taste as well. Lace dots. Golden yellow colour. Easy drinking, and I could finish a few of these over a week.

Did not care for this one. Too floral , herbal and grainy. By the second sip I was wondering if I was going to be able to finish it. Most of their other beers I have had are pretty good. This one pretty much sucked. Left 4 of the 6 with relatives. I hope they dont hate me later on.

Golden body with a mild amber hue and a medium off white head.  Aroma is fruity hops.  Flavor offers a unique hop bite which must be the result of the "English grains."  The malt adds some caramel and herbal earthy flavors are noted.  On occasion this beer becomes a pale ale with grapefruit nose and tastes.  However, this beer is not a pale ale.

This was a very good beer, with a delicious marriage of malt and hops.  I thought the carbonation was especially nice and full in this beer and helped add to the hoppy finish.  This would make a great session beer and I would definately buy this again.

Bottled.  Poured clear medium orange with a short cap of off-white, almost beige head.  The aroma was quite enjoyable.. strong alcohol-fueled herbal undertones with toffee, floral, and lighter fruity notes above.. caramel shows up and builds with warmth.  The flavor was a bit brash.. sharper boozy notes get in the way of the nice bready grains, and they amplify the strong herbal, floral, and fruity hops a bit too much.. really bitter and boozy in the end.. not bad, just unbalanced.  Thicker-bodied and sharp on the palate with a tacky, bitter finish.

bomber. pours copper/amber. minimal head.  im not sure of the hops used, but they seem fresh, though the aromatics are a bit less than par.  it smells like hop resin, sour citrus,  and candied lemon peel.   the taste is a bit spicy, slightly bitter, and nuances of pine and cedar.  still a bit of that sour citrus candy in the taste.  finishes fairly smooth, nothing lingering.  its very easy to drink.  i should have bought another one.

Bronze, well carbonated body with frothy, rocky head. Nice hop aroma, citrusy note, mildewy, airy. Easy hop flavor with some bitter-sourness. Borderline APA/English bitter. Solid, with a slightly metallic finish, and on the bitter side.

Rating #150. Pours an amber body with oily lacing and 1 inch of white head. Nose is hops and leather gloves. Tastes include pancake batter, more resinous hops, light fruits, strawberry ice cream, and creamy malts. Medium carbonation and full-bodied. Smooth and very drinkable with enough balanced hop presence to be enjoyable. Good brew. Underrated

12oz - Malty aroma of cardboard, caramel and earthy hops.  Pours muddy brown with a small head and decent lacing.  Flavors matches aroma but with the hops being more pronounced and a citrus zing in the finish.  Palate is sticky and tart.  Not a bad session brew.

I liked this one better than the hazed and infused.  Poured a clear copper color with a nice white head.  Aroma of citris and hopps.   Very well done ale with a great balance.  Hints of orange and corander.  Fine dry finish thatll have you reaching for you glass fast.
Gold color with white head.  Hoppy nose (citrus) and a similar but somewhat dimished body.  Not too sweet and a little grainy.

[619-20070914] 1pt6floz (w/ blankboy, jerc, tupalev). Light apricot and grainy boozy malt aroma has some fruit hints. Clear, amber brown body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Boozy green leafy-fresh hops has mild grain citrus notes. Medium body has a bit of a bitter finish. Nice hoppy beer.

12oz bottle, courtesy of argo0.  Thanks, Aaron!  Pours a bright orange color, slightly hazy; off-white head with large-bubbled retention.  Oily, resiny hops in the aroma: passion fruit and grapefruit; very oily and fresh; lacks a bit of density.  Pleasant, oily hops upfront (passion fruit, oranges); medium mouthfeel and light carbonation; very minimal malt background with a decent hop character; slight astringency coming through.  Medium, oily hop and dusty citrus finish.

(12oz bottle) Clear golden body with small off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, peach, floral, light bread.  Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, peach, some caramel, light bread.  Light-medium body.

Thin head which does not last long.  Nice hoppy aroma with some strange dog foodish aroma.  Kind of vegetal with some malts and a bit of rotten grass.  Not a very good aroma.  Medium hazy orange in color.  Sweet malts and some spicy hops in the flavor.  Still kind of sickly sweet and is not sitting real well in my stomach.  Finishes bitter and malty.  I dont know about this one.  Just not sitting well with me.

Thanks to Notalush for sharing his beer with me!  This one is slightly hazy, with a large-bubble, soapy head.  Quite a decent beer overall, IMHO.  Lot of floral hops in the flavor.  It is quite smooth and just slightly bitter.  It is a mild bitter, as it should be.  Its very easy to drink.

Bomber poured into an imperial pint glass - hazy orange beer, with a slight bit of froth on the top - semi-sweet, bready aroma, with some toasty qualities, a touch of gingerbread - soft carbonation - a tiny bit spicy up front, beginning more like a hoppy american pale - a biscuity british maltiness quickly tastes its place, as a few hops stick around, making the beer taste very bitter-like - - somewhat metallic and acidic in the middle - a bit of tangy orange flavor, a long-lingering biscuity/toasty taste, and some light cereal/grains - not really an english strong - more like a high gravity bitter.

Light amber pour with decent off-white head.   Some citrus hop on the nose, yet more of a carmalized sweetness.  Flavor was hoppy up front, there was something just a tad odd about it that I couldnt place.  Malt came through to balance it out.  Finish was nice clean and warm.

Really liked this the first time I had it.  Now, when I go to rate, tastes a little off.  May be bad bottle.  Anyway:  pale amber color with white head. Carmel and light hop smell. Bit of a metallic flavor -- light citrus -- dry finish.  Need to re-rate.

Upon its departing the 22 ounce bottle the beer presents a somewhat hazy deep amber orange color with a skyscraper sized creamy white head that lingers long and upon its vanishing the lacing seals the glass with a thick and clinging layer. Nose has a dominate malt aroma, sweet  and clean, hops provide a bit of fresh cut grass aroma, and a bit of butterscotch. Start is richly malted; the hops provide a nice bite at the back, top is moderate to full in feel. Finish has a fair to middling acidity, the hops perfect in the benign spiciness; quite dry aftertaste stays and stays, a nice representative to the style.

Hazy orange beer with a short lived big bubbled head.  Nose of toffee and candied oranges, with something chalky.  The flavor is dominated by orange rind and pine resin.  The body is surprisingly thin for a 6.5% beer and the hops could use something to balance them.

Poured just like a standard wheat beer...golden color with a whitish head.  Aroma is heavy on citrus hops...nothing bad, but nothing to set it apart from the crowd.  Flavor is all hops...nothing to set off the hops, and nothing but hops...very citrusy hops with a strong grapefruit feel.  Dry finish lingers for a while.  You better be a true and strongly dedicated hophead to snag up this beer, and sadly, Im not...  Definitely not my favorite from the folks at BB

Poured a hazy golden with a creamy/fizzy white head.  Aroma of some sweet fruitiness, a bit of toffee and bubble gum, and perhaps some citrusy and piney hops.  Has a bit of an off character to it.  The flavor however is smoother and more refreshing.  Flavors of orange juice, pine needles and a bit of a toffee earthiness lead off, smoothing it to a dry, perhaps somewhat one-dimensional finish.  Not the most complex of the style Ive had, but is reasonably refreshing and easy-drinking.

Quality beer but it just doesnt stand out.  Light amber color with a small white head.  Mild aroma with scents of pine, a little fruit, and a touch of toast.  Light to medium bodied.  Citrus and pine flavors that are backed by toasty malt.
Pumpkin to dark honey color, thin off whitr head. Nose is pretty hoppy. Grapefuits, pine and lemongrass. Mild in body, fairly tasteless and dull. Not the worst out there, just expected more.
This was a good beer...something worth trying...but not as "big" as some beers.

poured a nice coppery amber hue with a thin white head that had some lacing.   Aroma was typical IPAish caramel malts pine-like hops some citrus like fruits.  Flavor was had mild caramel malts with a nice hop finish.  I cant detect any earthy  notes that the commercial description indicates, but its still a decent beer.
A terrible offering for boulder. I like most of their beers but this was very off the wall and strange
Amber color and lots of British hop flavor. British hops in aroma too. I appreciate their effort to make a "hoppy" non-IPA.

Bottle--I expected more ratings than the 122 that have come before me.  The beer is an amber color with a medium head with lacing lasting throughout the entire drink.  The aroma was hoppy with the grapefruit undertones.  The taste had more of malts on front end, followed by the hops.

This is definitely an interesting take on the English Strong Ale style. My eye and nose lead me to believe I was looking at an American IPA. Pours a hazy apricot with a thin and fading white head that manages to leave a bit of lace behind. Sweet aroma of pine, pineapple, grapefruit. Medium body and carbonation. Taste of caramel, berries, a touch of citrus. Dry, earthy finish. Seems to be a sort of training wheels IPA if you like front end of IPAs, but not the back.

Nice flowery hop boquet, medium amber color with a small white head. Hoppy flavor with some malt present and the good ol English Kent Golding hop flavor some describe as dirt. I like it a lot. Medium to light mouth feel.

Dark golden ale, with an attractive eggshell  coloured head.
Strong aromas, spruce like, with a deep treacle  accented malt backing
lots of semi-sweet malts, sometimes getting really "toasty", good hop presence, piney, bitter.
Ok on the palate, not boring at least.
Overall very nice, but methinks the hopping was a tad too much for a real ESA,.

Golden/amber bodied, this ale has a modest head that still leaves much lacing in its wake.  Sturdy hop scents, mainly pine and grapefruit, dominate the aroma, nearly covering the toasty, bready malt.  The hops take on a floral/earthy tone in the flavor, some of the pine and grapefruit remaining, and the caramel, toast, and bread of the malts take on a larger role.  It finishes on a note of earthy bitterness.  Nice.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Pak Liquors, Indianapolis, IN<font size=-1>
Reddish brown nice big head. Not much aroma. Mild bland taste. A little thick but no malt balance, some bitterness. Not as much hops as the name implies.

(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a small white head.  Aroma of spruce, toasted malt, citrus, florals, and burnt caramel.  Flavor of pine, caramel, cardboard, and citrusy hops.  Unbalanced in both aroma and flavor.
22oz bomber-Aroma of hops and citrus on a light amber body. Taste of hops followed by some malt and a dry/sweet finish. Not bad.

Had this while watching the Buckeyes steamroll Purdue.  Nose of citrus & pine, dried fruit, perfume and flowers.  The brew pours a sparkling copper.  The big fully lasting super stiff & fluffy white creamy head leaves fair lace.  The brew is mostly like a good APA with decent bitterness, moderate acidity and a healthy citrus presence.  The finish is great, but more session than over the top.  The medium body is soft to lively and super creamy.  The finish feels crisp.  A pleasant surprise.

(Bottle) Pours an amber color with a large white head. Citrus and light pine in the aroma. Taste includes some grapefruit and a good amount of malt to balance it out. Above average palate and a great mouthfeel. I really enjoyed this beer, and would definitely drink it again.
Bittering hops overpower "subtle English" malt. Almost tastes oxidized. Not impressed with this beer or most others from this brewer.

(bottle - 12 oz) Rich amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is a nice mix of caramel malts and some rich and floral hops. Flavor is very floral and hoppy at the beginning with some citrus in the middle and a smooth, floral ending. Middle of the road beer really.
Draft sampled. Pours amber in color with a small white head. Aroma of caramel malts, citrus, and a hint of grapefruit. Flavor of citrus hops, caramel, light pine, and spices with a dry bitter finish.
12oz bottle pours out a amber topped with a small white head. A odd smell of some sort of fuel. A touch of hops but not very good. Thanks Indiana_red

Bottle pours a medium orange amber. Small sandy colored head. Faint fumy aroma of light malts.  Flavor was bitter and sour.  Harsh soapy cardboard flavors.  This cant be how it is supposed to be. Not good.
Draft. Nice refreshing hoped. Easy drinkable. Some biscuit malt flavor. Sweet hoppy aftertaste.

Bottle (22oz).  Clear copper pour, average frothy head.  Plenty of funky resiny hop aroma, a little roasty, cereal grain - yeah, thats the "UK" smell all right - lush.  The taste follows, mostly hops, but I get some slightly unripe currant taste, and a hint of rye - nice funky herbal finish.  Light body, mildly carbonated, fairly quick and tame finish, only somewhat bitter.  Decent.
Pours out a mostly clear dark golden color with a thin two finger white head. Aroma of hops and some malt. Grassy hops on the taste with slight pine, good malt backing throughout. Very drinkable

Bottle shared with Blankboy, Mabel and Jerc, courtesy of Blankboy.    Medium orange, small white head.  Decent aroma - some earthy malt, bread, but very little hops.   Good taste - nice hop bite up front, fresh lots of malt, definitely UK style.  Good session type ale, except now I see it is 6.5%...

In the 12 oz bottle from Beertopia. Pours a slightly hazy deep dark gold to light amber with a bountiful froth. Surprising aroma packed with green mown grass and pine needles. Wicked good fresh hop flavor that is oft-missing from the poorly protected Brittish ales that eventually find their way to Nebraska. If my experience with English Strong Ales involved this much bitterness, Id be a bigger fan.
Hazy light amber/orange color with a off-white head. Aroma of citrus and piney hops and sweet malts. Flavor of citrus hops, sweet malts and some sourness. Finish is also sour.

On Draught at the Dog & Pony, Renton, Wa.  Aroma is Earthy, with sweet caramel malt followed by a wide blend of hop flavors with citrus being the most noticeable. Appearance is medium copper with a moderate white head.  Flavor is a sweet/citrus hop blend forward followed by caramel, bitter hop character and a sour finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a medium carb feel and a dry finish.  Overall, this is very well balanced between a sweet hop and sweet malt character across the board.

Amber in colour, large lingering off-white coloured head, good lacing.  The aroma is of caramel malts, citrus hops, biscuits and pine.  The flavour is of caramel sweetness, pine and citrus, lightly toasty, floral with some light herbs.  Moderately bitter mouthfeel, meidum body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes lingering, citric hop bite, bitter turning sweet.  Good hop balance, dry, liked the malt that came out of this one.
355ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York for $1.79.
Purchased on August 20, 2007 and opened on August 22, 2007.
No date.

Bottle.  Amber to copper color with a frothy off-white head.  Nice webby lacing. Aroma of leafy hops, tea, and orange above toasted grain malts.  Flavor of light caramel and toasty malts  with underlying notes of dirt, lawnmower clippings and crushed up twigs. Citrusy-tea hop bitterness comes through on the finish.  Has all the elements to be great, but a little too leafy and woody IMO.

Bottle.  Pours a clear burnt amber and supports a small dusky white head.  Bready aroma with hints of caramel.  Flavor of mildly roasted malt, orange zest and almonds with an earthy center and a bitter backstop.  Texture is slightly thin but the finish is very dry and snappy.

Pours an amber colour with small frothy off white head. Aroma of grapefruit hops, red fruits and sweet malts. Initial taste begins with a light malt that is sweet. Pine makes its presence but soon gets overwhelmed with an astrigent citrus rhine bitterness. Sides of the mouth stick with that bitterness for an average palate duration. Minor head retention and some lacing of the glass. Medium body and dry finish.

12oz bottle pours amber with a short white head that stays pretty well. Aromas of slight pine and a touch of grapefruit with good caramel behind that.  Flavor is some decent citrus notes blended nicely with some caramel malts, a touch of spice at the finish.  Medium body with lively carbonation but an overall balanced brew.

My bottle (650ml) shared with tupalev, jerc & mabel. Pours a clear golden-orange with an average size frothy off-white head. Simple but nice aroma of hops backed by caramel malt along with hints of fruit, spices and biscuit. Flavours pretty much the same, hops and caramel malt and a light, dry  bitter finish. Medium bodied. Pretty good, I enjoyed it.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of roasted, heavy hop notes of citrus and pine, and a light yeast smell of broth, with wood and a very light scent of indecernable dried fruit. Head is frothy, off white with excellent lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is a slightly hazy dark amber. Nice balance in flavor that starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic and finishes heavily bitter. Palate is light to medium, slightly oily but finished dry, and it has a lively carbonation. A nicely hopped English strong.

Poured an amber color, ok initial head, weak retention, ok lacing. The aroma was citrus and grapefruits. The flavor followed suit, citrus and grapefruits, light resinous notes over top of caramel and toffee malts. An overall earthiness made this a pretty enjoyable beer, apricots and melons also underneath. This exceeded my expecatations, especially at 3.49 for the bomber. Nice stuff!
Bomber; nose of ivy hopiness; translucent copper with a small offwhite head; flavor of light hop bitterness with some light sweet caramel.

Had this beer on 6/30/2007.  Aroma is a fresh hop scent with light citrus tones.  Color is a deep golden with very good carbonation and a nice head.  Taste is hoppy and bitter.  Starting with a medium body smooth with a faint fizz in the end.  Finish comes right in with a hoppy flavor that is a bit citrusy and has an almost wood like taste to it.  There is a very faint hint of malt and it all ends with a nice bitterness.  I thinks its got  too much hops and not enough malt.

Citrus and sweet aroma, like most pale ales.  Light copper color with zero head retention.  Not too overpowering on the hop level, which in my opinion is the way a pale ale should be.  Some mouthfeel, but could use more.

Bright coppery orange, creamy off white head.  Subdued nose of piney cedar that warms into soft florals and grapefruit.  Floral woodsy bitterness rides on a light earthy nutty sweetness.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, drying, lightly bitter finish.  For me, this makes for a near perfect session ale.  Nicely done....

Bottle. Amber, smallish white head. Very mild hops in the aroma with light citrus, zippy  lemon and grapefruit hints. Flavour is rather mild, with similarly modest citrusy hops and mild resin. Sweet malt backs it all up. Average palate. It is pleasant, and would make a drinkable session brew (albeit a tad strong for that) but the restrained hops leave me wanting more.

Pours an amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of citrus hops, caramel, slight pine, and some yeast.  Flavor starts off with the citrus hops, caramel, and sweet malts.  Finishes with a slight toasted malts and a little bitterness.  Overall a somewhat decent brew.

PIney, caramel aroma -- plenty of hops there.  Some chemical orange in there  Bad label, fair cap, pretty nice looking mostly clear brown, rusty brew with a thin meringue-like head.   Drier than I expected, prominent hops as advertised, not super fruity.  Some off sulphury flavors and aroma, especially when your nose is close to the waterline as you tip the glass.  An almost gelatin mouthfeel, spritzy and fruity in the finish.  Hops build a bit over time.   Fair.
Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a slight head.  Aroma of orange, hop, grapefruit, and some pine.  This is nice...some sweetness with a nice balance of hops.  This is a good beer!!!

Bottle Crystal clear amber ale with a large, frothy, off-white head. Great retention. The nose is a complex, churning eddy of caramel, praline, toffee, pine and grapefruit with lesser notes of brown sugar and nutmeg. Great balance of flavors. Sweet toffee and tannic grapefruit pith with mild to moderate acidity. Medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation. Lengthy, astringent, mildly pungent finish.

12oz.  Poured a clear deep copper with a large long lasting off-white head.  Decent grassy and earthy hop aroma with a light pine mixed into a semi-sweet malt.  The flavor was piney, earthy and malty with a citrusy and bitter finish.

bottle.  poured a dark orange with a small whit head. smell was sweet malt. the taste caught me off guard with a  earthy tone than a more familar and a bitter finish thanks to the hops present. no alcohol in the taste which i expected of the style but i guess thats because its only 6.5%.

12oz, no date.  Clear orange with a one finger off-white creamy head, pretty good retention.  Spicy pine and flower petals with some toffee and toasty malts are the aroma.    Flavor has earthy, spicy, and grassy notes dominating, toasty sweet malts seem to be backing everything up quite well.  There is a lingering bitterness that I wasnt really expecting, as all the hops seemed to be aroma hops.  Bitterness peaks at a 3, and the finish is grassy.  Lowish carbonation with a medium body.  How low can an English Strong Ale be to be considered one?  6.5% doesnt seem that strong.  Oh well, this was pretty good.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Draft at The Falling Rock in Denver. Poured a clear orange color. Head was one finger tall and reduced over a few minutes to a thin film. There was a bit of lace on the glass at the end. Aroma was hop dominated and reminiscent of crushed green leaves and fresh grass clippings. There was also a hint of graham cracker. Dry with a thin mouth feel. Flavor was earthy overall. Like herbal tea, a touch of caramel, and wood. When I say wood, I dont mean oak, its more like what I would imagine chewing a freshly plucked twig might be like. Earthy. Interesting.

22oz Bomber 
A deep golden color with a strong hops aroma and flavor.  This has some earthy tones to the flavor and the finish was quite dry and nice . A deep rich use of malts.  This was a great beer to drink.

Appearance: Huh. Look at that. Pours a clear, orange body with a wispy, bubbly white head.

Smell: Toffee malts with a handful of white pepper and zesty, citric grapefruit.

Taste: The taste of toffee, though with very little sweetness. The bulk of the taste is of tart, tangy grapefruit with plenty of bitterness. Finish is dry, bitter, but somewhat quick.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Doesnt really remind me of anything British. Shows what I know, I guess.

Very impressive - nice floral hop
 flavor with a smooth caramel cereal malt base. Estery fruit blend with a nice dry, bitter finish with a twist of tang and spice. Well done chaps -except for that butt-ugly bottle art

Bottle: Pours a transparent copper orange with a spotty-lacing white head.  Aroma of earthy piny, resiny hops and some sweet caramel malt.  Body starts fairly full with a decent light caramel malty sweetness balanced with big English bittering and flavor hops toward a grainier lightly citrusy finish.  An interesting hoppy English strong.

22oz bomber. On the nose the aromas of green apples and spice for aroma. Orange/ copper body with good size head and a good amount of lacing. Flavor has the apples not over sweet and the spice hop is not overdominant. Smooth on the palate with a mixture of sweet spice and bitter aftertaste.

Pours a clear copper with moderate carbonation. Medium white head, good retention, lacing. Aroma is wet, tangy hops, light citrus, mild sweetness. Almost vinous. Taste is a nice mild caramel with light spices. Spicy hop presence. Body is light with just a slight oiliness. Finishes with light bitterness. A fun, approachable beer.

9/07/2007:  Boulder Beer Company Cold Hop is a deep gold in color with a lasting, puffy, ivory-colored head that leaves some decent lacing on the glass.  The beer is clear with a moderate amount of visible carbonation.  It really does appear to be a beautiful English pint!  The aroma contains floral, citrus (grapefruit), and touch of pine hops.  The flavor is not quite sweet, but not really too bitter either.  Its earthy with orange and grapefruit citrus and some perfume/floral qualities in the slightly dry finish.  Cold Hop has a medium-light body and is slightly oily on the palate.  It goes down fast and easy.  All in all this is a nicely constructed English Pale Ale/Bitter.  One could easily sit down and enjoy an entire six pack and then some...
12 oz bottle from Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #72 for this beer...

Bottle from Rivers Bend. Poured clear copper with a large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate floral hoppy aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium bittersweet citrus flavor with a medium smooth bittersweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

Bottle.  Pours clear amber with a small, frothy, white head, diminishing, fair lacing.  Aroma is average malt (grain, cereal), heavy hops (flowers, perfume, pine), average yeast (sweat) with notes of peach.  Light bodied, alcoholic texture, average carbonation and a bitter finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness and acidity, heavy bitterness.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2007 Wow! This is a refreshing and different beer. Aroma of grass, hops and some citrus. Pour was a cloudy gold with a nice 2 finger white head. Taste was very dry and bitter. Tons of grassy hops and earth with a slight oily citrus element;all the while maintaining that dry English feel. This is a classic beer to try next to an Arrogant Bastard or American IPA to distinguish our use of hops in American Strong ales as opposed to our neighbors across the pond (ummmm...I realize that this is made in the US)
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours a clear amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, largely of malt, with a bit of a citrus/hop characteristic as well.  Taste is an interesting ride from malt to citrus to hop and back again.  Citrus and herbal/grassy notes linger after you finish.  Above average, though unspectacular.

Bottle: Translucent amber, copper hued, large foamy off-white head, fairly clingy lacing, no noticeable carbonation. &nbsp Nose of 

wet hops, not all that strong, and subtle orange rind. &nbsp Flavor is a little astringent, hop oriented but moreso a bitterness associated 

with orange rind. &nbsp Seems a bit stronger than your normal "British Ale", but thats fine with me. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. 

&nbsp Lingering citrus peel bitterness on the finish. &nbsp Tiz okay, but the astringent bitterness somewhat detracts. &nbsp Does lighten up 

as it warms. &nbsp Enjoyable while being somewhat average.

This starts with a sweet and bready nose, pouring a clear amber, with a minimal white head.  In tasting this beer, it runs more to the sweeter side then the bitter.  There is a slight bitter finish that lasts for a while, however, for something called Cold Hop, Im disappointed in the lacking of strong hop character in it.

12 oz bottle purchased at Spirits Red Bank. Poured a very nice looking orangey/amber with a great white creamy head that easily returns to a quarter inch thickness with the slghtest agitation. Aroma is malt dominant with lots of caramel and molasses but also has some floral hop notes dancing around as well. Flavor is rather one dimensional with lots of bitterness and not a lot going on. This is just another average beer from Boulder.

Pours oragne with an off white head. Aroma is grassy and grapefruit citrus notes with the herbal notes somewhat masking the citrus. Some citrus flavors, good herbal grassy hop flavor. Nice bitter finish, and somewhat dry
Strong ale. No wonder I was so tired.  tasted like an IPA.  Like it very much. Sorry to Piscator for not sharing.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2013 Sampled on draft at Rivertowne Pub in North Huntingdon PA this beer poured a dark bronze color with a medium sized white head. The aroma was moderate grassy and fruity hops. The flavor was light sweet malts and an intriguing mix of fruity and grassy hops. The hops are not overwhelmingly strong but really coat the tongue and linger. The beer is almost slick with the hops. I find myself burping up the hops later. Tasty.

Clear copper pour with a thick off-white head.  Lots of pineapple, cherry, caramel and touch of diacetyl in the nose.  Medium body with quite a bit of chewy malt.  Doughy malts mix with piney hops in the body.  Finishes bitter with a heavy dose of grass and citrus.  Good.

22oz. Bottle:  Lightly sweet, medium bitter aroma.   Smells of caramel malts, honey, piney hops, resin, dough, bread, and toffee.  Poured amber in color with a small to medium-sized off-white head that shrank but lasted a long time.  Good lacing.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium bitter.  Tastes very earthy with notes of hops, rye, resin, salt, and bread.  Light to medium body.  Thin, watery, sticky texture.  Soft carbonation.  Dry finish.  Overall, underwhelming.

Bottle from Capones.  Turbid orangy deep coppery color with 1-finger off-white head.  Aroma of bready caramel malt, hops, tangerines, pineapple, black pepper.  Medium body which goes toward hefty, providing very dry hoppy flavor notes, coupled with tangerine, pineapple, and peppers.  Stays hoppy and rather bitter, coming off like a souped up, extra hoppy British bitter with a heck of a lot more malt thrown in for good measure.  Enjoyable and unique.

On tap at the Mad Mex in Robinson. Looks like a ubiquitous pale american lager except that it is ever so slightly darker. Fruity flowery and hops in the aroma. Initial taste is pretty  hoppy and a bit peppery.  That is odd because Ive never tasted any pepper in a beer before. Interesting and unique. Be careful, this beer hides its alky content rather well.  No carbonation. Reminds me a bit of a mild IPA in its finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Tallahassee, Fl. - Market Sq Liquors - 12 oz bottle. Medium orange, slightly murky, sticky white head, good lacing. Fresh fragrant aroma - light spruce, some floral notes. Good citrusy hoppiness, but not overdone. Good malty backbone with some caramel notes. Mouthfeel decent  could be creamier. Solid entrant from Boulder.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2008 Pours the color of honey w/ a full, creamy froth. Head retention is superb receding to a 
full silky canopy w/ some spattered islands and a complete creamy ring of lace. 
Aromas of fresh malted herbs and aged citrus rind. Full nectar w/ ample, creamy residual effers. Nice! 
A big malty backbone supports a bright hop component. Flavors come alive w/ a brisk force 
and splatter layers of aged malts on top of refreshingly snappy hops. Mildly sweet w/ rustic  nuances 
of citrus rind and mild caramel. The finish is bittered perfectly and dry leaving a nice hop burn 
to linger. I want more! Very well balanced. I can taste the English influence.
Highly recommended.
Pours a clear golden orange with a medium white head.  Faint piney aroma with hints of floral and fruit hops.  Taste is slightly piney and floral with a cardboard finish.  Average.

Rats, one of those ratings where I typed everything in and then lost it when I waited to long to press "add rate". Abbreviated review. Earthy aromas and flavors. Some licorice and citrus. Just unclean and uninviting.
fruity and floral just like it sasy smooth to drink and decent hop burn NOT EXCESSIVE like i refer but a nice british style none the less nice work
Bottle sampled. Pours light amber with a decent size off-white head. Aroma of citrus, floral hops, and caramel. the flavor is sweet, caramel, citrus, fruit, with a floral bitter finish.
Bottle. Pours orange yellow, white head. Aroma is hoppy, tangerine, wasabi chickpeas. Flavor is subtle wasabi chickpeas, tangerine, rye.
Golden body, nice white head, English hops (Fuggles/Goldings?) and some bready malt in the nose. Nicely balanced, moderately sweet, herbal, floral, earthy bitterness.

Bottle and served in standard pint glass: Clean golden hue with a lasting frothy head and good lace. The aroma has classic English vapours of biscuity and toffee malts, aromatic (EKG methinks) and grassy hops, a slight apple and apricot esters. The taste profile is close to the nose with more smooth hop bitterness over layers of grainy and caramel malts. The finish is a tad chalky and lingering. The mouth feel is equally soft carbonation and dry finish. A solid example of a fresh English Strong Ale.

22 oz bottle pours a hazy orange body with a one inch offwhite head that strews some patchy lace on the glass. Toffee and caramel malt aroma is balanced by floral and earthy hops. Some red apple esters are present. Medium bodied with a zesty carbonation. Taste features a toffee maltiness that eventually gets overwhelmed by the various hops. Earthy, floral, and a hint of citrus hops bitterness lasts into the finish. Nicely balanced, but Im a bit confused over the style. Tasty and very drinkable.

Some pine and earthiness in the aroma,  Brilliant amber in color with a quickly dissipating eggshell head.  Dusty dry maltiness, some crackers, mild toffee, with slight citrus hop bite.  Lingering sweet and sour flavor.  I rather enjoy this quaffer!  Bravo to TAR!

Bomber.

Pours golden with some floaty matter and a small white head. Tolerable nose of grassy hops and the first sip is actually quite nice, definitely coming through with a British malt profile. But as I get further, I get more disappointed. The beer is grainy, some metallic hops, too alcohol-sticky, and overall disappointing.

22. Pours crystal clear amber on the dark side of medium. Light sudsy white head. Moderate sheets of lace. Nice floral, tangy citric (orangey) nose. Medium body, tingly carb, citrus/bitter-forward flavor right from the attack. Mid-palate has some nice very faint tobacco and a bit of caramel to undercut the fruity hops, but its really about the hops. Definitely tell this is made with American ingredients, even though the style feels rather British.
Courtesy of zathrus13. Poured amber with off white head. Aroma of hops and citrus. Flavor was the same with the exception of a sweet caramel background. Well balanced finish.
clear ruby caramel, no head, stale hop nose, crisp palate, slight tang, crispy hops and delicate malts, excellent ballance, warming, well done

Another brew from Boulders Looking Glass Series. Pours a nice clear yellowish-copper. Big thick foamy off-white head sits on top and then settles to a nice layer covering the brew after a few minutes. Some lace is left on the glass as the foam settles. Sweet caramel malt up front with a great fruity hop aroma coming in next. Some berry, hint of apple, and a touch of citrus fill the nose. Sweet malt fills the mouth. Light and very smooth. Then a wonderful fruity hop flavor comes in. Fruity apple, hint of berry, touch of citrus. A very interesting hop flavor. Tasty and smooth all the way. Very easy to drink. Not much on the aftertaste other then a bit of malt sweetness. A tasty brew overall.
22oz. Poured a very golden color with a little white head. Aroma is some what hoppy. Taste is smooth with a nice hop finish but not enough for me though.
on tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Nice hop aroma, floral. nice hop bitterness, some citrus pretty good offering from boulder

Pours dark golden with a thick foamy head. Aroma is earthy, fresh, decent amount of malt and floral hops. Flavors are light citrus, sweet caramel, biscuit, bit of metallic, grapefruit on the back end. Still a hint of spiciness and some pine. Finish is the grapefruit more than anything else, fairly dry. Its a nice take on blending the American and British IPA styles. I certainly wouldnt call this an english strong. Feels too light on the body, not getting any esters or alcohol notes.

Pale Amber Color with White Head. Nice Sweet Caramel Malt and Light Hops on the Nose. Flavor is a Bit Metallic...Some Caramel, Toast and Pine Flavors...Light Citrus...Bittersweet Dry Ending. Hard to Get the Metallic Taste to Go Away. Hopefully Just a Bad Bottle.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper-orange with a white head that quickly dissipates to a thin film.

The aroma is fruity melon and metallic hops with a little pine.  Some skunky notes come out on the second pour.

The flavor is caramel malt with a fruity (melon) and pine hop bitterness in the finish.  The mouthfeel is medium to full with low carbonation.

Overall, it tastes more like a subdued American IPA or Pale Ale than anything British.  I was expecting more of something like Odells old Cutthroat Pale Ale.
A highly drinkable and enjoyable ale.  Reminds me of a toned down APA with a whole lot more class and malt.  This might be Boulders most consistent offering -- would make a nice 6pack.

Dark copper with a medium head.  Strong, floral hop aroma with some residual malt sweetness.  It almost smells like a bag of East Kent Goldings 

with some Cascade added.  Bittersweet taste.  Strong malt body, but with a bit hit of earthy, English hops for bittering.  Its kind of like a cranked English IPA, but a little sweeter.  Nice.
