22 oz- rich, nutty, and flavorful. hops were allegedly earthy, and more in the english style, but they tasted pretty pnw to me. Did taste like more of an american pale ale, but there is some complexity that indicates this is something different. Nice.

22 oz bottle. Dry and piny hops on the nose. Sweet malt. Grassy. Very aromatic nose. Pours golden copper with decent lacing down the glass. Slightly disappointing flavor: hops and malt give way to a watered down metallic finish. Earthy malt tones develop after warming. Decent carbonation. Slightly watered down finish.

From a 22-oz bottle shared with joebrew, pours a clear orangish amber brew with a slow dissolving off-white head that leaves behind a good lacing and ring. Aroma of citrus peel, grapefruit and some lightly roasted malt. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated with a moderately bitter grapefruit, honey bread and spruce tips. Finish is hopyy bitter with a tart grapefruit aftertaste. Definitely appeaching a West Coast IPA caliper beverage but still an Engish Storng Ale.

Pours a nice orangish/amber, with virtually no head.  Nice biscuity malt hints as well as some nice floral hoppy accent as well as a hint of honey.  Suprisingly bitter, with just a hint of sweet caramel malt on the front palate, but the hops quickely take over, and give a grapefruit like citrus acidity.  Not bad
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: 22 oz bottle.  Poured a beautful golden/amber with a small, active head.  Aroma of British bitter with citrus, but the taste is smooth and hoppy.   Has some sweet malt up front and then hoppy bitterness.  I really enjoyed this one.

The 22 ounce bottle poured a beautifully clear reddish amber colored beverage with a modest frothy off-white head that lasted well and left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was less hoppy than I expected but there was a fair amount of citrus hop nose present accompanied by a subtle caramel malt note. The body was medium-full with soft carbonation and a smooth creamy texture. The flavor starts out lightly sweet but quickly turns moderately bitter and remains that way through the medium-long finish.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful cheddar orange with a lively body and a slightly off-white head.  Apricot seems to be the dominant aroma in the nose; quite pleasant and light.  Flavor is floral apricot with a nice sweet/bitter finish of grapefruit.  Nice mouthfeel; flavors are dispersed quite nicely along the tongue.  Very enjoyable brew; Ill buy more of this for sure.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: The aroma is quite English with English hops and yeast. The malt character is caramel like and the taste is nutty. The appearance is amber with a decent head. The palate is smooth. Wow a fantastic beer.
This is really winner, the hops are more piny and subtle than Amercian styles of this kind. The malts are light and refreshing, crisp tastings with no astringency

A fresh hoppy beer that is on the same level as Hazed. The head is a little darker and the hops present give it that earthy smell and flavor. Not a traditional British style IPA or hoppy ale, this has slightly more hops and a better taste.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Beautiful pour, nice head. Strong fruity aroma. Real hoppy, no doubt about it. Not sure how much "British-style" this is, but its good. Finishes well, and the mouthfeel is great. Its seasonal, grab it soon.
Poured a clear yellow color with a white head. Had some lacing, and has hints of sweet hops, spices, and flowers. Finished light bodied with a dry sweet hop taste on the tongue.

Bracing floral hop aroma. Tickles the palate. Coppery amber color with a massive frothy head that laces. Medium bodied; light carbonation. Like it were bottle conditioned, mate. Light caramel malt sweetness, balanced by fruit and flowers. A bit gummy sweetness as the finish approached. The finish is very florally flavored and balanced. It is really very good. Mild and flavorful. Great.
Pours a darkish amber color. Aroma is hoppy, floral and sweet. Flavor is hoppy and sweet.Finish has some bitterness but the fruit sweetness overpowers it.

Big citrus and fruit aromas with mild spice notes. The massive dose of ganja cant go without mentioning either. The body is a pale, slightly tan tinted, golden color and holds a diminishing white head. Flavor is all hops with citrus, floral and herbal notes. Finish is sweet and fruity. Has a mildly oily feel to it. Just too hoppy for my tastes though.

Pours a clear orange amber with asmall off white head.  Smells of spicy hops, grapefruit, and citrus.  The taste is very bitter hoppy, and defintely get some spice big time too.  Very interesting beer.  Nice citrusd finish, leaves a big grapefruit taste in the back of the throat.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2007 The aroma on this one is strong enough that after pouring I smelled it from a few feet away. Rich and sweet with earthy notes. Pours a nice amber, borderline orange body, little fizzy head thats off-white and settles rapidly. Does have some nice lacing. Aroma is strong, not too sophisticated but smells like you would expect a "real ale" to smell--which is a great thing. Flavor is sturdy with malt being the dominant participant and hops taking a far back seat. This beer has a nice sweetness that is subtle and well presented. Palate is  earthy with fruity notes and some English hop character, a bit of alcohol, and a smooth lightly bitter finish that does satisfy. This is good beer done great and I would absolutely indulge in its deliciousness any time. 

Note: The label says that this beer was brewed with the help of Charlie Papazian and is actually a variation on a recipe of his; amazingly good call on Boulder Beers part. Hats off to you fellas!

Amber,lasting beige head.Fresh citrus hop nose. Starts citrus, malt mid,molasses as it warms. Lasting bitter hop end. Light alcohol heat. Good lace
Very nice.

Clear copper. Small white head. Flavor and aroma of spicy, resinous, piney, earthy, citrus hops with lightly grainy malt support. Surprisingly hoppy after reading "british-style ale" on the label. Medium body, balanced carbonation. IPA is a more accurate description. Solid.
Hoppy aroma, pine resin, syrupy, grapefruit, dank, marry jane!  Pours amber/orange.  Smooth hops, citrus, pine resin with a heavy malt sweetness.

Bomber purchased at Countryside Liquors Clearwater, FL for only $3.39. Seems like a steal. Pours a light copper hue with decent off white head and lacing. The aroma is of pungent floral hops that are strong enough to put out real floral hop spiciness. It also leans toward smelling wet hopped too. I cant pick up any malts hiding behind the hop bouquet. The taste starts with pine and floral hop bitterness. It may not be pine creating the extra bite to the bitterness but rather an intense floral spicy hop bitterness. Nicely done too. Other big floral hop beers Ive had dont have manage to create the balance with the aid of this unique bitter hop spice kick. Once the whole hop experience has wrapped around the tongue a few times a rich pale and slightly grainy maltiness comes to the surface to squelch out the hops. The beer ends with mild floral hop flavor and residual malt sweetness. Rather yummy, all in all. The best English type IPA Ive tried to date.
Pours hazy yellow with small white head.  Nose is grapefruit and pine hops.  Flavor is the same with some malt balance and some diacetyl.  Tastes like an IPA to me
Draft.  Hazy, battery acid in color.  No head.  Buttery, hoppy in aroma and taste.  Dry - evaporates quickly off the tongue.  Sampled @ American Beer Fest in Boston

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2007 22oz. bottle.  Sweet, citric aroma, hoppy, floral and fresh, with notes of orange, grapefruit, spice and faint cedar along with some lightly toasted malts and even a slight estery touch.  Clear medium amber color with a lasting, fine, head and attractive lacing to match.  Flavor profile is clean and hop-focused, citric, gently piney, woody, moderately bitter and balanced by a toasty, lightly sweet, grainy malt backbone, finishing smooth and resinous .  Palate is creamy and very smooth, with a medium body.  Pleasant lingering fruity hop character late.  A pretty enjoyable pint.

Nice session-ability!
Drinks with a far less intense Hop profile than the Hazed. The beer pours beautifully, copper body and a tall ivory head. The aroma smells of sweet cereal malts, toasted honey nut bread and a lovely array of English and lighter American hops. Some earthy spicy Spruce accompanied by some light citrus. The mouth feel is creamy and buttery. Overall, the best way to describe Cold Hop is to say its like Hazeds British cousin.

Bottle from Kingdom Liquors Brandon, Fl. Pours a clear copper with a small but lasting white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of floral and earthy hops with a nice light malty sweetness. Taste is the same as aroma with a nice earthy hop flavor. Medium thin mouth feel with a well balanced bitterness. Very good.

Well I liked this quite a bit, it reminds me some of Rogue Brutal Bitter, which I like. Anyway, the nose was hop dominated, initially lemon-citrus focused, with hints of pine, but it became more floral. If Im not crazy, these were Goldings hops in large quantity. Touches of biscuit hiding beneath it.  Towards the darker side of amber, full head. Flavor was crisp and very clean, it may be in English in inspiration, but this was an american yeast. Caramel and biscuit malts, resiny and floral hops. Finish was balanced. Palate was medium. Not sure of the strength, but this bomber went down easy and fast, and I could feel a little something when I was done.

Bomber poured a clear amber with a small lasting light amber head. Aromas of carmel, biscuit, citrus, earthiness and light pine. Palate was light bodied and crisp yet smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and citrus with a crisp lingering moderatly bitter finish.

Clear and light copper-amber. Thin, patchy head. Decent lace. Somewhat rich texture; fitting carbonation level. Didnt really care for the malt flavors much. Made me think of alcohol-soaked grains, bread crust and peanut shells. Hops were like resinous spruce tips. Citrus aromas circled within my olfactories. Not necessarily a bad beer, but it didnt mesh with what I like.

Hmm, I had a different experience then those below. Strong hop nose, pine resin and citrus. Malts were toasty and provided a nice warm melted caramel flavor that meshed well with the bready english malts. Not balanced, but probably never tried to be, but a unique flavor for what could have been just another IIPA.

Bottled. Beer is clear, medium amber with a moderately sized, white, frothy head. Diminshes mostly.

The aroma is a pop in the nose. Hoppy with aggressive moderate notes of pine and resin (in that order), repellant rotting grass clippings, hay, lighter notes of grapefruit oil; Glimmers of light notes of malt (toasted grain and caramel) escape from underneath.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic with a long, lightly bittersweet, trace acidic finish. Rotten, dirty notes in the rets.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2007 Bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is medium amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, husks), moderately hoppy (resin), lightly yeasty (dough), with light notes of cat urine and vegetables. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, unclean. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.  Got a very chemically/vegetal sample the first time (from bomber) and promised myself Id give it another chance (this time from a 12oz).  It still does have some of the same problems, but it isnt as overwhelming this time.  The Pine Sol -like hop aroma dosent help though, nor does the husky/grainy character. Not a very good beer, but certainly not as bad as the first sample.
